Thanks to Secret Santa for this.  Pours a clear straw yellow with a big frothy white head.  Aroma is citrus, hop and wheat.  Taste is wheat with a blast of amarillo hops.  Grapefruit on the palate with a soft hop bitterness.  Very nice beer.

Bottle. Pours a golden yellow color with a frothy white head. Aroma is very hoppy with alot of grapefruit and citrus, along with some tropical fruit, bready and biscuity malts and wheat. Flavor is also very hoppy with grapefruit, sweet orange zest and citrus, along with the grapefruit, wheat and bready and biscuity malts. The body is light to medium with a powdery dry mouthfeel. Overall a really nice session able brew!

355ml bottle cellared for quite a while after I bought it at Ølbutikken in Copenhagen in May 2010. Clear, golden-amber body. Only the very last pour is slightly cloudy. Airy, white head leaving spotty lacing as it goes down. Prominent smell of lemony hops with floral and piny hints. Superfresh flavour of tropical fruits, fruity wheat and earthy malts. Mild, bittersweet ending. Very thirst quenching (Tromsø, 24.02.2011).

Love having this stuff around.  Pours orange-amber, with white head.  Aroma has big citrus, with prominent notes of grapefruit, touch of tropical fruit and esters.  Sweet fruity esters up front lead into grapefruit, and more grapefruit, with a touch of bitter citrus rind, finishing fairly sweet but a touch bitter.  Great session beer, delicious.

Pours a golden straw. Small white head that fades superfast. Little bit of lacing. Was expecting this to be cloudy, mostly because the bottle said it may be, but it was pretty bright.
Beautiful hop nose. That is pretty much it. The hops drown out anything that may have been there. Except there is a faintly perceptible yeastiness.
A little bit blander than I thought it would be. There is a definite hop flavor, then what seems to be watered down beer. I was expecting more malt and hints of a wheat beer. There is a somewhat muted yeast flavor. 
No too bad. A little on the thin side, but nothing terribly wrong. Hops stick to the mouth the entire drink. Carbonation seems to be released the entire time as well.
Not bad on a hot day. Not very flavorful. Not sweet and not annoyingly bad. I wont pursue it, but wont refuse a free pint.

Judging this beer based on the fact that its a wheat. Unbelievable. I love it. Theres a bubblegum quality going on and that lemon just rushes through. I dont think Ill drink a better wheat than this. The body is perfect. The mouth feel is perfect.

I was really surprised how good this beer was, and my expectations are always high with Three Floyds. A refreshing hop brew. I could definitely have a few of these. Maybe the best wheat ale Ive ever had. Great stuff.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2012 The only American Pale Wheat Ale that is actually worthy. IT is a grapefruit bomb in all aspects.
Golden body with a white head... this beer has the body of an angel. Tastes like a wheat beer from Three Floyds should taste like. Has a bit of a malty mouthfeel with a hoppy aftertaste. Delicious
Bottle. Clear golden with small white head. Flavour is malt, wheat, hops, fruit, sweet, peach and bitter.

(12oz bottle).  Pouts hazy golden with white head.  Aroma has wood, citrus, but also ginger?  Taste is malt sweet but it also has a bite on the end.  Thin bodied and slightly bitter finish.  Quite peppery. More like a saison.

Pours clear light amber with a decent white head. Aroma is very very fruity. Elder flower, pine apple, apricot, lime and light piney notes. Just amazing. Some yeasty notes in the far back. Taste packs the same fruity punch, but the hops are matched by banana-ish yeasty notes and some malts are evident too. The king of wheat ales, a fantastic session beer.

First let me start by saying i am not a huge fan of wheat beers and try them all the time in hopes that one day i might join the wheat parade. If there ever was a wheat beer that i truly enjoyed this would be it. Gumballhead really is an American Wheat beer that doesnt suck.  Aroma is pine, citrus (especially lemon), with some wheat in the back.  Taste is similar, very hoppy, fruity, and a refreshing amount of wheat. this is not like any wheat beer I have tried and I am really diggin it.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is sweet, hop, , peaches, malt. Flavour is sweet, hop, peaches, malt, wheat, pine. Nice beer.
Unclear amber of color with a white head. An aroma of flowers, hops, citrus and thea. A flavor of citrus, applesjuice, hops and citrus.
Clear apple-juice color with thin white bubbly head. Aroma was apples, hops and sweet cream. Taste is mild wheat, crisp with nice hop profile.

From notes:

Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a thin, fizzy half finger white head that immediately disappears leaving only the smallest spots of lacing.

Surprisingly hoppy aroma for the style with a prominent earthy pine presence as well as hints of citrus and tropical. Im picking up pine needle, grapefruit and lemon peel as well as some faint malt but not many characteristics of a wheat beer. Slight bread/yeast and citrus fruit but not much in the way of spice/clove. It smells great just not like a wheat beer.

Medium bodied with a good balance of earthy and citrus hops, crisp, light fruit, citrus peel and spice. There is some earthy pine needle and citrus/tropical fruit notes from the hops but it isnt as hop forward as the aroma suggests. The wheat beer characteristics are much more prevalent in the palate and flavor. Good balance of bread/yeast, citrus peel and clove notes. Clean, crisp and easy drinking with a slightly dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2011 If you havent had this beer all I can say is you havent had the best wheat beer in the country. I thought when I first tried Rabbid Rabbit from 3Floyds I had found something. That was just moments before I had tried Gumballhead. This beer is the reason I started my adventure into tasting and rating beer. Its citrus finish isnt overpowering, but yet just right. I can have one or ten and the balance of flavors are  never sacrificed. You now what I mean sometimes the citrus and hops are so overbearing you cant pick up on any other flavors. Not this beer. Lemony love makes this my beer of choice threw the summer. 3Floyds bless you throughout eternity for bringing us this extraordinary brew! I have many wonderful moments with this beer and many to come. I dont tailgate Michigan Football games with out it. GO BLUE! So so so refreshing. Dont ever stop making this beer or I will stop breathing.
UPDATED: JUN 16, 2014 Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is earthy with notes of sweeter yeast, hops, pine and fruits. Taste of peach, citrus, wheat, hops and grass. A nice fresh beer.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Aroma is floral and citrus, like an IPA.  The appearance is golden yellow with a thin white head that dissipates.  Taste is hoppy and well balanced.  Not too bitter, slighlty IPA, but the wheat creates a nice balance.  Not your typical wheat beer...not really like a wheat at all.  Very sessionable brew overall

Pours cloudy golden, with a small white head. Smell is of piny, citrusy, and grassy hops, alongside a large dose of wheaty aromas. Taste is very hoppy for a wheat ale, strikes a nice and interesting balance with the wheat. Medium body and carbonation; a pleasure to drink.

Pours a perfect amber. I was a little apprehensive in purchasing something with this name. I am very happy that I did. The aroma is of floral hops. There is a lasting head that remains thin. Taste is of hops and slightly aged malts. I was expecting a wheat beer like advertised on the label. not really th case. I was pleasantly surprised with a beer that tastes more like an ipa.  so for actual style points I would reduce the score but this is a very nice brew.
Clear gold color with low head and great lacing.  Smooth with slight bitterness.  Lemn and hops , a sort of light IPA.  Good brew again from Three Floyds.

bottle split with and courtesy of Wallace. pours a cloudy orange body with nice thick,creamy white head. aroma is lemon, citrus, and amarillo hops which balance the wheat accents nicely. mouthfeel is thin and smooth with notes of a standard wheat brew - fresh hops, yeast, lemon, and citrus.

Clear, yellow color with a lingering white foamy head. Ruby red grapefruit in the nose. Light in body, very smooth. Refreshing. Lightly sweet, bready, and a soft bitter hop finish. Unique and enjoyable. I can see why this beer is so popular.
Bottle: Poured a orange color with a white head. Aroma is a mix of hops and wheat. Taste is sweet wheat along with drinkable hops finish.
Tons of grapefruit notes. No head on the pour, which saddened me a bit but was extremely refreshing and goes great with pasta and chicken <3
On tap at brewpub. Fruity aroma--passion fruit and mango? Flavor is sweet tropical hoppiness. Delicious and sessionable.

how a wheat beer should taste and add in some tasty floral / citrus notes and youve got an easy drinking golden yellow american wheat.

again 3 floyds succeeds in creating a beer how the books say it should taste look and smell, and then add not overbearing but amazing undertones and significant flavors that make these brews unique. very drinkable,

smells spicy, like hops and spruce/citrus. Extremely clear and watery with no head at all, not much carbonation.  Tastes spicy and artificially sweet with a sour aftertaste.  Reminds me of an osage orange.

12 oz bottle courtesy of thomcatr3t.  Pours a clear blonde with a small white head leaving specks of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is floral and pine hops with some wheat.  Initial taste is a lemon zest followed by some pine.  Finish is wheat, bubble gum, and banana.  Light body.  Medium carbonation.

Smooth session beer that is unspectacular but nonetheless pleasing. The aroma deceptively smells of alcohol, but the taste is bland, with almost no hint of alcohol and some subtle bitterness. The high point of the beer is the thin, almost creamy texture. I could drink these all day.

33cl bottle at Brewdog Aberdeen. Pours cloudy amber colour, with bubbly white head. Nose; citrus fruits, yeasty, floral. Taste; smooth and light, lemons, slight wheat, hay, tart finish, Easy drinking wheat beer.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar, København, Denmark.
Hazy yellow colour with big fluffy white head.
Yeast and bitter hops in aroma.
Flavour is yeast, bitter hops, fruits and citrus but not much wheat.
Short aftertaste.

On tap at the Theater Square Marketplace.  Aroma is of citrus and is very enticing.  Minimal head, but a nice amber/orange color.  Taste is very hoppy for a wheat ale and the combination of hops and wheat may be what gives it that citrus taste and aroma.  Light on the palate.  Overall an amazing beer with an unexpected, but very welcome taste.

12 oz. bottle from Woodmans in Madison, WI.  Pours golden orange with a foamy white head.  Grassy and citrusy hop aroma.  Much more bitter than any wheat ale Ive ever encountered.  The generous amount of hops added to this brew makes it come off as more of a pale ale than a wheat ale.  And a damn fine pale ale at that.  The hops are of grapefruit and pine and overwhelm most of the wheat flavor.  A great beer but it doesnt fit the typical wheat ale profile.

A: Pours a yellow gold with a nice white head.

S: Lots of hops atop a nice wheat background. Mild sweetness, but the big players here are all the little hops that found their way into the delectable brew.

T: Hops are ever-present--theres not so much a bitterness from them, but a tropical sweetness thats really enhanced by the wheat. By far the best-tasting wheat beer I have ever encountered.

M: Fairly light bodied with a nice creaminess to it.

D: Unsurpassed drinkability. This is one that I wouldnt mind loading up with several cases of to drink throughout the warmer months, and I plan to do just that next year.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-01-2009

Notes from 11/27/2010
12 oz. bottle from Woodmans Madison

Ar: Huge lemon zest aroma, a touch of floral hops.  The lemon is nice, but it does border on the astringent side.
Ap: Clear, dark straw with a bit of light orange, 1" frothy white head.  Good lace.
T: Light lemony sweetness, nice tart and bitter notes on the finish.
P: Fizzy, light, highly refreshing.

O: Excellent wheat ale.  So often these come out insipid, but the tartness and touch of bitterness on the finish make this interesting enough.
Nose of elderflower, bitter hops, feel is mild, carb is mediumweak, taste is bitter hops, weak sour apple

(draft @ Local Option - Chicago, IL) Hazy orange pour with a very thick and fizzy white head. Very inviting and mild spice and wheat flavor with detectable hints of coriander, lemon and grassy hops. Very refreshing wheat and spice flavor at the start with a nice counterbalance of that lemon and the floral hops. The more I drink it, the more I really like the flavor. This would be the ultimate summer session beer.

When I first tried this beer, I didnt like it. The pine and citrus was unlike anything I ever tasted. Now, it is one of my favorites. It is amazingly refreshing and finishes very clean. I agree with other reviewers that this is not a traditional wheat beer. My local liquor stores say it is flying off the shelves.

Pours a golden color with a big head and some good lace. The aroma is lots of fruity hops and a little onion. There is some pine resin and lots of melon in there with a light bit of perfume as well. The flavor is nicely spicy with tons of hop fruitiness and a mild banana and berry character as well. The beer overall is pretty well balanced between fruity and bitter characteristics that are dominant and well suited to the subtle flavors. There is a bit of onion in the finish and just a shade of lime and crackery malt.

Excellent. The freshest hops I have ever tasted. Strong aroma of grapefruit from the amarillo hops. Lightly fruity flavor underneath all the hops. Not really a wheat beer, but not an IPA either. Gets points for being somewhat unique.

12oz bottle thanks to jrallen34.
Appearance : Crystal clear pale yellow. Small creamy head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Nice hops mixed with wheat. Quite fruity. Resinous notes. 

Taste : Fruity hops with some what. Finish is a bit resinous and fruity. Some wheat also.

Overall : Not really what one would expect with a wheat ale. Id expect a little bit more wheat. Not sure this should be in the Wheat ale style.This is still quite tasty. Very drinkable and quite refreshing. Nice fruity hops with an enjoyable light wheat backbone.
Bottled. Hazy golden color, short head. Aroma of wheat, citrus, bit cheesy, slight sweet. Bit too sweet taste, wheat, bit bitter. Not my kind of beer to be honest.

Thanks much to sherm1016 for this one. A clear deep golden brew with light fruity hop aromas and a nice bouquet of flavors. Much hoppier than any other wheat Ive ever had. This one goes down surprisingly well. Finishes with a nice lingering hopness. Not bad at all.

This one is great.  Smells grapefruit &  pineapple.  2 finger head to thin ring with not much lace.  Taste is hoppy, grapefruit.  Appearance is clear and yellow.  not hazy like most wheat brews.  Best in the style and definitely unique..

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2011 I have had this on many occasions in the past, enjoyed on a Saturday night at DMK Burger Bar in Chicago, IL while eating with friends.  Fantastic summer brew.  Aroma of lemons, hops, and crisp malts.  Appearance is a slightly cloudy yellow with a thin head.  Taste is fantastic, slightly more hoppy for the style but thats Three Floyds MO.  Will continue to drink again.  UPDATE - I recently had this on tap at the Globe in Chicago, IL and it was flat out incredible, fantastic when its fresh and on tap.

I had my doubts being a wheat beer / Belgian disliker (hater seems too strong).  This is nothing like a typical wheat beer.  Floral (to me) aroma.  Great bitterness with the lighter palate of a wheat, but the bitterness is on the front and the "wheatness" in the background.  This does seem to be more of a pale ale.  I really enjoyed this and will try it again to have on hand when Im not quite in the mood for the in-your-faceness of an IPA+, but wanting something with better, more refined flavor than a pilsner.

This was a very odd one for a few reasons. First drink I was absolutely unimpressed, but when I continued to drink this citrusy delight every drink tasted better. Also, I would like to mention that I searched for this beer high and low for two months before I finally found it. Now to start with my review. This beer is heavily carbonated, the aroma smells of grapefruit. When poured into a glass it has a golden amber appearance. Overall this has become one of my favorite summertime beers, and is nothing like any wheat beer you have ever had before.
Bottled. The aroma has citrus, wheats.  Golden coloured beer with a white head. The taste is slightly bitter, sweet, has some malts, citric hops. Okay.
Bottle.Pours amber with a white head.Aroma is peachy ,malty ,wheat and fruit.Flavor is sweet and fruity with some malty notes.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice beer

Aroma:Hops come across cleanly in the nose, grapefruit aromas.

Appearance:Light amber in color, lots of fluffy white head.

Taste:Nice hoppyness in the first taste, not overwhelmingly bitter. Theres a slight refreshing fruityness in this beer. The aftertaste, even from the first sip is nicely nutty.

Palate:Easy drinking, mild body, slightly cream, good carbonation.

Overall:This is a great sessionable IPA. Theres not a huge amount of complexity in this beer, but its got lots of drinkability.
Golden colored brew. Wheat and hops in the aroma. Flavor is more like an ipa, citrus, lemon hops, some wheat. Very drinkable.
Bottle. Low but lasting white head. Hazy yellow body. Mild sweet appe pear aroma. Slightly acidic pine lemon flavor with a fair amount of hops bitterness. High carbonation, long aftertaste.
On tap at the brewery.  This is great and refreshing.  Very hoppy for a wheat.  More like an American  pale ale. A very well built beer.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 250910.
Yellow with white head. Aroma of yeast and wheat. Flavor with fruity esters and spices.

Bottle. Poured a clear golden with a small white head. Citrusy hops aroma with a bit of sweet caramel. Flavor is citrus hops, grass, sweet caramel, and a little peppery spice. Medium bodied with a light carbonated tingle. This was my favorite go-to beer for the summer of 2010. I really enjoy the malt/hop combo.

12 oz. bottle. Light golden pour, small head. Citrusy hops in the nose, medium body, somewhat low carbonation.  Finish is dominated by hops, I wasnt expecting it to be quite so hoppy.  Tastes like an IPA, but feels like a wheat.

Clear light amber color.  Nice amount of fluffy white head.  Very little lacing left around the glass.

Aroma is EASILY my favorite aspect of this beer (and while its great in a bottle, the aroma really shines on draft) - MASSIVE waves of fruity floral scents dominate - it almost smells like bubblegum at times.  VERY impressive.

Flavor is a bit more subdued but still wonderful. Medium sweetness, light body - nice hints of citrus and hops smoothed out well by the wheat.. Nice balance all around really.

This is the beer that got me into "good" beer and I just keep coming back to it time and time again.

FANTASTIC!

A Mew rate. Bottle thanks to the Cad.Clean gold with a thin white head. Gloriously fresh and bright and exciting but not at all over the top. In fact, this is probably the most drinkable American beer Ive had and as an Englishman, I love that about it. In fact, I could easily chug the whole bottle of this all the way down with no problem. Nice citric notes, just a peep of the wheat, that develops a considerably in the finish. Shit. I drank it all. Not even thought about the numbers... Thankfully Tom has another bottle. Numbers ahoy! Damn good beer.
Clear - weird for a wheat based beer with yeast added. Long-lived white head. Robust pine aromas. Hops up front with a thin underside; crisp. Delightful beer; an IP melded with a wheat beer.

The color is a slightly hazy golden yellow with a thin cream-white head. The hops come through in the aroma with a dry citrus scent that lays on top of an underlying fruit sweetness. That same balance is evident in the flavor as well, with a lemony hop flavor contrasting with a light fruitiness. This one is fairly light bodied, which combined with the light but pleasant flavors makes this one an easy drinking selection.

Bottled
Orange clear color, small white head. Exotic fruity hoppy aroma (pineapple, peach). Light to medium bodied. Flavor is similar to aroma: exotic hoppyness (peach, apricot, pineapple), sweet malts. Wheat ale? More like an APA. Good one though.
Bottled (thanks fonefan). Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is wheat, spices and a lot of fruityness and some mild earthyness. Flavour is wheat, some mild fruits and spices.
UPDATED: JUN 15, 2015 Interesting Wheat beer.  More hops than usual. Citrus flavors. Serving: Tap
Perfect summer beer for warmer days as it is not heavy.  Easily drinkable but does leave a hop after taste.  Not a typical wheat beer.

Small bottle, bought@Ølbutikken, København. A hazed, deep gold colored beer with a low creamy near-white top. Smells delicious; summerflowers, dried apricot and honey. Also a scent of perfume and lemon. Quite sweet for an American Wheat, but the sweetness is rounded fruity and wheaty. Fruity flavoring hops is there to balance. A good amount of bittering too. Smooth and easy on the palate. Sugar tones and fruity hop linger in the finish. Session-beer for the summer afternoons, and more. Really good stuff.

Got on tap hours old from brewery, great wheat ale. Aroma was very pleasant can smell the hops with which your mouth is about to be overloaded with, apperance was a nice hazy golden color from its second formenting of the added yeast during conditioning. Taste was unbeliveable a medium almost full bodied feel as you swallow, first sweet and than bitter as you get the full affect of the hops. Great ale to toast to friends

Pours a light golden color with a full diminishing white head.  Citrusy hops in the nose, soft tangerines, and sweet resinous pine.  Tastes lightly of sweet citrus, lightly bitter, and the wheat rounds things off nicely.

Bottle.

Dark golden with a white head. Surely it was a very nice Wheat Ale. I particularly liked the nice aroma, a lot of apricot and citrus. A lot of hops, some lbanana, medium-carbonation, orange, pineapple, light mouth feel, refreshing and invigorating.

Poured from a 12-ounce bottle into a pint glass.  Pours straw-like, copper.  Aroma is citrus, pine and banana.  The amarillo hits the nose pretty hard.  Taste-wise, this certainly one of the best wheat beers Ive had.  Just finished a side-by-side comparison with Gumballhead clone that I kegged a few days ago.  Since FFF doesnt distribute in Michigan, I should be okay for a few weeks.  As always, well done.
My favorite wheat ale Ive had - basically a wheat beer with nice hops.  Pours a nice cloudy dark haze, wheat front, hop finish. Have had from Indiana and at Brickskeller in DC.

Aroma: hops and citrus, lemony, but slightly more sweet smelling; Appearance: yellowish, honey colored, steady flow of bubbles, bubbly head upon pour that quickly diminishes, frosty but not cloudy; Taste: in terms of drinkability, I have to say that this beer is one of the best Ive had so far, theres something very, very unique to it, but I cannot for the life of me put my finger on what exactly gives it this uniqueness, you can taste the hops, young green hops, and you can taste the grain, and you can certainly pull out the citrusy aspect, and theres a very subtle peppery aftertaste, but, either the blend is more than the sum of its parts, or theres some aspect that I just cant describe very well but that makes it incredibly tasty, Palate: great in sips or swallows, fills the nose and teh mouth equally, carbonation makes it feel full, but taste makes it light and refreshing, absolutely wonderful; Overall: dont judge a beer by its label...I, personally, for some reason get turned off by beers that have new age, comic, or gimmicky artwork, hence why I never explored Three Floyds until a friends bachelor party, after that, I was hooked by their superior brews, I recommend this to anyone, so much so, that this is the one that Ill be buying to share with others throughout the summer

8/13/10.  12oz bottle courtesy cbfobes!  Cloudy light yellow pour with a fluffy white head that sticks.  Light soft wheat aroma with citrus, orange, and a bit of cat pee.  The flavor is sweet at first with citrus then transitions into yeast and hops. Not bad!

Malt is lacking, I caught a bit of DMSor something off on my bottle. I have had great bottles before. Finishes sweet and hoppy, bitter and citrus. Mouthfeel is light and crisp with decent carbonation. Overall a very refreshing hop forward beer that I would never call a wheat but that is cool with me.

Poured from a twelve ounce bottle into a weizen glass.

Pours a straw golden color with a clingy head that starts at one finger and dissipates. Cloud is quite mild for a wheat.

Aroma is amarillos on the front. The hops dominate the aroma with no malt aromas present. Citrus hops really do dominate the nose.

Flavor opens with earthy hops. I say earthy because that is what I get from amarillo. Hop yield to citrus and grapefruit. Malt is lacking, there is nothing there for a wheat twang that I expect from a wheat beer. Lemon is the predominate flavor. Finishes sweet and hoppy, bitter and citrus.

Mouthfeel is light and crisp with decent carbonation. Very refreshing with the lemony hop hit.

Overall a very refreshing hop forward beer that I would strain to call a wheat. That being said, it tastes good, and 3F has never been known for sticking to style.

Reviewed 07/19/2010
12 oz from drowland via trade.  Pours a nice golden color.  Great sweet aroma.  Nice bitter start to a good candy sugar finish!

Pours a dark golden clear with a white head.  Can taste the wheat sweetness.  Large hop bitterness which is different from most wheat ales and definitely distinguishes this beer from other wheat beers.  Unique beer.
Yellow and clear, sparkling. Has a white head, mostly diminishing. Aroma os heavy hoppy, citrus notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter. Dry texture. Lively carbonation.

Bottle: Pours a cloudy golden color, with an average white head. Smells of piney hops and citrus; with flavors of lemon, orange, and HUGE piney hops, Light Sour and Bitter taste, with a thin texture and bitter finish.

amazing wheat beer!  Aroma is great, piney hops orange-lemon citrus, grassy malt.  pours deep gold with a nice 1 inch head or so, some lacing on the glass.  taste is lemon citrus with orange coming in at the finish, strong hoppiness for a wheat beer, but its perfectly done.  sour on the front of tongue followed by light sweet lemon citrus maltiness and finishing with light bitter orange citrus.  goes down crisp and smooth, very refreshing.  A masterpiece of a wheat beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours clear golden with a white head.  Aroma is hop forward with a heavy emphasis on pine resin and grapefruit, a note of berry, leading into wheat in the background.  Flavor features more of a lemony citrus and pine hoppiness, backed by a very clean, toasty wheat flavor.  I honestly dont think Ive tasted wheat quite this way in a beer before, and its really good.  An excellent American wheat; my only complaint is the lightness of the palate.
Poured from 12 oz bottle, pours with a very light color and small white head, nose is full of hops and pine, has great citrus and hops finish to it, very very good!

12 oz. bottle.  Hazy gold pour with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus, hops, pine and wheat.  Tastes very hoppy, floral hops, lemon and strangely bubblegum.  Very unique wheat beer.  Never had one better.  Refreshing, awesome.

The nose is predominantly dry hops.  As I learned at the brewery a few weeks ago that they dry hop all their beers.  This does have a distinct wheat flavor.  This is probably the most in your face and hoppy wheat ale I have tried.  Great beer!
IPA-like nose.  Light gold in color.  Like a wheat ale with citrus notes and a strong hop finish.
what a wonderful wheat ale. Tastes like a good IPA but with more malt. Very drinkable.

Bottle. It pours a slightly hazy golden body under a small, white head. A bit neutral on the nose, but nice. Wheaty and hoppy with some peppery hints. Grapefruit and pinecones, and a lemon-peel whiff. Grapefruit, some pinecones and a slightly spiced touch in the flavor, with wheat and some caramel, bready hints in the back. Sure hop driven. Full-bodied and nicely carbonated, finishing rather bitter. A wonderfully refreshing and quenching beer I really enjoyed after a long, boring day a work. 100723

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar. Golden yellow pour, small white head. Aroma of thick, citrusy hops, fruits, sugar, pine, grass and caramel malt. Much like an IPA. Taste is light but complex with a nice malt character, followed by lots of citrus, grass and a light touch of grapefruit. Low carbonation, medium duration, medium-full body. Very big and punchy for a wheat beer.

Thanks to hophead101 for sending me this beer as a surprise extra. I have been wanting to try this one for a while.

The beer pours a clear yellow color with a white head. The aroma is strong resiny hops with some wheat mixed in. The flavor is resiny and piney with some wheat. Medium bitterness. This is basically an American India Wheat Ale and it is delicious. Slightly thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
pours golden with little head.  good lemon taste, slightly sweet with a hint of bubble gum.  a great summer beer.  very sessionable on a hot day.  my 2nd 3 Floyds beer and Im not disappointed.

I am hooked on this beer. I think it may depend on the keg you get, but it can be spectacular. Smells good, looks good, tastes good. If you can, you must get it from th tap. I assume it is called Gumball Head because it has a taste similar to traditional gum. It has a slight after teaste that gies away after the first drink.
First smell hints at an inevitable disappointment. Very fruity scent. Taste is not too bad, even likable. I might not ever drink this one again, but while I have the bottle, I am going to enjoy it.
Pours a clear dark gold with white head. nice aroma of wheat malts caramel and fruity American hops. taste backs it up. great balance and good clean bitterness but does not linger. awesome session

A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. Bottle was fresh from Indiana, body was super dry, no real wheat character i could notice, didnt have that typical amarillo taste i would expect either. it was good, and if it was on tap i would buy it, but nothing id trade for again.

At first I thought this beer tasted rather off, like the flavors or something just werent coming to the front...or my tongue was having an off-day. Fortunately, I saved a few bottles for another time and it was really special the second go around. A light yellow, almost champagne colored body allows for a bubbly, carbonated head that stays with the beer down the glass. I couldnt really pinpoint the flavor here, and Im not going to bullshit you like others do by saying the most random of comparable flavors or foods, but the tastebuds detected some wheat sweetness with a touch of citrus and earthy qualities that most come from the Amarillo hops. The perfect medium body gave the beer a German Weizen quality unlike any other American Wheat I have tried. This beer is simply top-notch.

Bottle.  Clear yellow pour, medium carbonation and a nice strong hops and fruity aroma (smells more like an IPA.)  Flavor is intially light hops, lemon, and finished with an aftertaste of bitters.  Solid drinkable summer beer.

Bottle (Beers of Summer at OTH). Pours clear amber with a small white head. Aroma is pine, citrus, and some florals. Flavor is pine, grapefruit, and lemon. Light/medium mouthfeel...very refreshing. This is a great summer session beer.

tasted at the Beer of Summer event at Oldsmar Tap House. Pours a golden yellow with a light white head. Aroma is sweet, hoppiness, grass, citrus. almost confused with an IPA. Taste some earthy piny, grass notes. very hoppy for this style. Medium mouthfeel, not clamy, pretty decent finish. This is a really interesting and very good brew.

Bottle - Pours a cloudy yellow.  Small white head.  Some lacing.  Grassy aroma was big suprise.  Combine that with the hoppy bitterness and this could be confused with a pale ale.  Litght bodied.  Been wanting to try this for a long time.  Overall an interesting beer because of its uniqueness.

12 oz bottle from the brewery, served in a weizen glass. Pours clear yellow-golden with a small, rocky white head and a few small particles of sediment. The head fades quickly to a minimal cover but leaves some lace as it goes. The aroma has prominent notes of citrus along with some floral and fruity notes from Amarillo hops. There is also a touch of yeast and grass, with some wheat. The flavour starts with a restrained sweetness up front and develops a tangy acidity through the middle. Hops are present all the way through and these grow towards the finish. The finish is long with hops and citrus lingering on the palate. Palate is light-medium in body with a watery texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is a very unconventional example of a wheat ale, but its very, very good. It is more assertive than most wheat beers and much more complex. I was disappointed with the initial appearance, but the aroma makes up for it. The Amarillo is a beautiful complement to the wheat. A great summertime patio beer for beer geeks. 2010-06-29

Bottle. Pale yellow colour, Sweet mix of wheat and citrus hops in aroma. Notes of wheat, mango, melon and vegtables in taste. Quite thin body, but that fits this kind of beer good. Tastes like a very sweet and wheaty pale ale.
At Mikkler beer bar.Hazy golden colour with medium white head.Aroma of wheat and good heavy malty.Flavor is flowery and fruity with mild tosted nose and well balanced finish.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Light hazy yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is moderate malty (caramel) and heavy hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet, heavy bitter, but a good balance.  Light body, thin. Very fine.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a weizen glass.  Aroma is very spicy hops, not much lacing, and medium smooth body.  Pours a light hazy orange, with small white head, and not much carbonation.  Taste is spicy aromatic hops (pine and grass), some wheat, and a hint of lemon.  This beer is an interesting marriage of american pale ale and american wheat ale.  Slightly overrated for me, but worth a try.

Yum Yum Yum. This is one badass wheat beer. Note that is is listed as a "wheat ale" for the style as this does definitely have the hops to earn the ale. Smell is a light hoppiness that teases you to try. Color is that of a clear wheat. This is a light and crisp ale that has a smooth, nonchalant sweetness that is finished with a clean hop-bite. I really need to go grab more of this. FYI- South Minneapolis/Richfield to Casanova Liquors is about 30 minutes at 6PM on a Friday if you drive as fast as me. Thank you Casanova- I will enjoy my $129 worth of craft beer. Minnesota, state that I love and have lived in my whole life...lets hope we can get a ton of good breweries like Three Floyds flooded throughout the state.
Clear golden with a medium white head. Hoppy aroma with lemons and wheat notes. Flavour had wheat, lemons, and hops. Finished dry and bitter.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, yeasty and distinct hoppy. Fruity, mild estery and hoppy flavoured. Citrusy, peachy and slight grapefruity. Dry and bitter into a lasting fruity finish.

Good but not great or world beating, pours clear and cold color.  Just a slight hop flavor and a lot of grass, finishes amazingly clean and refreshing.  Manages to be light and smooth but still have flavor.  Good summer beer for beer nerds.

Pours a thick, hazed yellow color, thin, white, creamy head, from the 12oz. bottle courtesy of bulldogp04 (thanks, dean!): A lightly juniper hopped nose joined with notes of citrus, florals, past-prime lemons, cracked wheat, and dough. A smooth texture rounds out a light to medium-bodied feel with soft carbonation. The taste is not as hoppy, or fruity, as the nose puts out. Instead, Im getting a full-on embrace of herbs and dirty grass. Drinkability: Is it IPA or is it wheat? Simple characteristics, but not so simple to park it into one style over the other. Its a melange. Pairing: Lemon meringue pie. Rebuy: Ok. #458 on 09062010, DG.

Big thanks to Erik for this as an extra!

A-pours a slightly hazed golden yellow with a dense pure white head and a great lace left behind.

S-the nose is big and quite hoppy and oily.  lots of pine and citrus in the nose, lemon comes in at the finish with light notes of acetone.

T-taste follows the nose, lots of hops and notes of acetone in the back.  pine, citrus, and lots of grapefruit. notes of wheat, a good bit of lemon,  a touch of acetone in the back and a nice light bitterness.

M-very smooth on the palate, high carbonation, a touch of graininess on the back with a good bit of carbonation, slick on the back of the throat and oily on the palate.

D-this is a hugely drinkable wheat beer but more like an ipa.  ftons of hops with a light note of wheat. the acetone in the finish is a little off putting but the hops are huge.

phaleslu kicks ass mofo!  So the info sez wheat, but my eyes and nose say IPA.  Bold amber with a hint of haze.  Only a hint though.  Head is rich and creamy, be it short.  Nose is beautifu apricot and tropical hops.  Bit of creaminess, but mostly spicy hoppy goodness.  Taste is sweet and tart.  Not sharp IPA like the nose.  No orange citrus of your typical wheat either.  Bit of white grape and hint of aspirin, but way down low in the back/.  Tastes like the best pale-ale ever, but not a wheat, or an ipa.  Its good, I just dont know what the eff it is.  This is rating 700 for me, and I chose this bottle specifically.
Draft. Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of grass. Flavor is lemon zest, citrus, and floral notes. Probably the best wheat beer Ive ever had.
Very cool what 3 Floyds did here.  This Wheat beer has a big hoppy flavor and lots of citrus in the finish.  I passed on this beer a lot, but now am sorry I did.  Its really good.

05-JUN-2010, bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken".
very light color - slightly hazy - white head.
Very hoppy nose. Cannot be a wheat beer? Well, perhaps it is, just a very hoppy one. Then the strong mineral note comming out as petrol like in an aged riesling. A flaw? Anyway, I like that:)
Nice refreshing beer.

Sampled at the 3 Floyds event at the Brickskeller.  Pours a clear, orange amber with a cloudy, white head.  Aroma is nice, citrus, oranges, perfume, light hay, grassy.  Flavor is sweet, sugary, apples, citrus zest, oranges, light candy, grass.  Medium bodied and lightly tart.   Very bright looking, bright smelling, bright tasting.
Pours hazy yellow. Aroma is heavy on the grapefruit and citrus hops. This smelled so juicy and tasty.  Flavor didnt disappoint either.  Crisp, citrus, lemon, grapefruit.  Very refreshing beer.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2011 Tap at Birreria Paradiso. Pours a clear, dirty yellow with a thin, white head that leaves excellent sheety lace all over the place.  Has a fresh, West Coast IPA nose. Whoa. Taste is butterscotch, fresh West Coast hops. At first this is a bit watery and thin-bodied and then with a good food pairing the body becomes richer, more raw oatmeal and earthier full of fresh grist and wheat protein. Spritzy carbonation. Very nice.355mL thanks to TheTomG. Pour is light, clear yellow with a medium, rocky, isohumulone heavy head. Big lace. Amazing dank hop nose. One of the dankest, most tropical hop noses Ive encountered like straight Citra and Simcoe pellets. Taste is lighter, definitely wheat, with some oatmeal grains that dont meld super well with the incredible tropical hop aroma. Something odd like pool cleaner comes through that Im not a fan of. Bitter palate. Really nice one though. 8/4/6/4/14=3.6

Bottle thanks to Wedgie9. Pours a clear apricot with a white head. Nose is muted pines, citrus and spice. Taste is where it really shines. Wonderful full citrus mouth with some pine needles and wheats.

Botella, courte sy of Pinball. Aroma of exotic fruits, great hoppiness, citrus and grape fruit. Very good mouthfeel.  Pleasant good ripe fruity and piney flavour with grape fruit, some peach and the malt is has its struggle to get through beneath all the hops.

cloudy yellow, smooth white head.
aroma is hoppy, citrussy hoppy, flowery, very nice aroma of fruity notes with quite some lemon, exotic fruits, also notes in the aroma that resembles grass, but it all matches up real well. Supernice aroma
flavor is exotic fruits, lemon, dry hops and flowery hops, malty base.
palate is real nice, smooth yet prickly.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Clear golden with a small, frothy, staying, white head. Lots of small bubbles. The head leaves fine laces. Aroma has lots of grassy hops, good grapefruit, light citric. Lowish carbonation, fine dry mouthfeel, slightly thin texture, though. Flavour is hoppy, piney, grassy behind a strong peach and grapefruit note. Low maltiness. A bit basic yet very drinkable.

Bottle from Ølbutikken CPH. Pours weak golden with a medium sized head. Aroma of pine,grass and peaches. Taste is light sweet with a fair amount of bitter hops, pine and resin. Fizzy carbonation. Long citrus/pineapple finish, not bad.

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share! Pours a hazy yellow with a bright white head. The aroma is overtly hoppy with a wheaty twang. Lemon, grapefruit rind, coriander, vanilla on the nose. The flavor is hop forward, very citric, and has a wheaty finish with a hint of bitterness. Very nice. I want this in a can on a golf course.
This isnt a common wheat ale. The bottles appearance could have told me that. It stands out. The hops are prominent and I enjoy the after taste.
Thanks to Telios for the taste.  Nice and light and hoppy.  Great beer for a summers day.  Loved it.

From a bottle.  Pours clear golden orange with minimal head.  Wonderful citrus aroma that is filled with orange and grapefruit.  There is some pine in there, as well.  Flavor is wheat with strong citrus hop presence.  The citrus in the aroma is more subtle in the taste than it is in the aroma, but it is still present,  especially in the finish.  Great blend of orange and grapefruit flavors.  Probably would go great with eggs and toast on a saturday morning.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ chrisos Back In The UK Tasting.Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy to fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wheat, moderate hoppy, fruity, peach, citrus, moderate yeasty, smoke and rubber notes. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, peach - apricot. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100522]

Faintly citrus nose.  Hazy gold colour, little (but pleasant) head.  Light but delicious tangy sweetness and a lemony finish, but rounded and well-done (no furniture polish here!). Start-to-finish excellent, and a pleasure to drink - another winner from the Munster magicians.
Bottle at Chris Os. Bright yellow with a white head. Aromas of stewed apple, pineapples, cinammon and pine. Flavours of banana, pineapple, grapefruit. Sweet, hoppy and malty finish.
On tap at Mikkeller. Clear golden body with a medium white head. The aroma is peachy hops, grass, spruce and light caramel. The flavour is peach, resin, citrus and some rubber. Medium bodied.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2010 bottle at chris -o ... golden yellow ... soft lemon fruits ... zezty ... fizzy banana ... bit thin .. light bitter in linger 3.0 ... mua dinner light hazy yellow ... sweet zezty lemon fruit nose ... very fruity soft ... light banana ... light lemon ...  well balanced

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours a clear gold color with about an inch and half white frothy white head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is citrusy/fruity (tropical fruit, apricot, orange peel) and flowery hops, and some bready malt.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but the fruit hop flavors dont come out quite as strong in the taste.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, its a bit coating.  Drinkability is pretty good, its smooth and quite sessionable.  It wouldnt be hard to drink quite a few of these at a time!  I think its a good brew overall, I like it!

Tasted 2010-05-20. From tap at Mikkeller bar, Copenhagen. Clear, orange. Powerfull hoppy aroma. Citric, grassy, very fresh taste. I didnt really get the wheat in the flavour, but none the less a very good beer.

Bottle. 

Golden orange with a small off-white head with good retention.

The aroma is all about fresh, slightly raw citric hops. Lovely lemon and grapefruit notes. Grass and resiny with notes of tobacco. Gentle wheat notes. The smell gets more blurry and round when the yeast goes in the glass. 

The flavor is actually much lighter than expected. Sweet caramel and hints of wheat. Grassy and citric hops, slightly less aromatic than in the smell. The finish is mildly bitter and a bit oily due to mellow carbonation. Ends mildly sweet with hints of grassy hops.

Moderate body.

For a wheat ale and considering the low ABV, this is quite impressive, and to be frank I think it is the first American style wheat beer Ive had that wasnt completely pointless. But more aroma hops would have made it more in line with the cocky exterior.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Clear golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of citrus, hops and pine needles.
Fruity flavour of citrus and hops with notes of pine needles and grass.
Hoppy finish.

Bottle pour gives clear light amber with fairly brief frothy white head. Aroma hops and wheat.  Taste grapefruit, malts, hops, wheat.  The hops initially come at you but quickly back off for a fresh sweet finish. Mouth feel surprisingly full.

Interesting beer, nice summer drink.

Obtained in a trade (thanx Brundo4!)  12 oz bottle into a Duvel tulip.
Light golden amber with a one-finger head which quickly settled to a coating.  Lacing was thin but lasting. Nose was lemon zest, wheat and floral, with a sweet bready undertone.  Good carbonation.  Taste follows the nose.  Hops are there and up front like an APA or IPA but they are quickly beaten back by the malty sweetness.  The aftertaste remains sweet but with a nice dry finish.  Mouthfeel was smooth, thin and pleasantly sticky.  At a little over 4%, this beer is definitely sessionable.  Yep, already I want more...

Flaske: Flot pilsnergul let diset øl med et fint skumhoved. Superlækker duft af citrus, men hveden kan man ikke ane. Smagen er frisk og lækker, primært citrus med et lille humlebid som afslutter. Lækkert at se at amerikansk øl også kan være sessionstrength og fantastisk alligevel.

Bottle. Thanks to fata2683 for the trade. Pours hazy yellow/gold, thin, highly persistent white head, spotty lacing. Nose is nicely hopped, with a touch of the "sticky hop rankness" that is so near and dear to my heart, plus wheat sweetness; flavors are quite earthy, with a lovely lemony aspect, some candy and spice also, very broad and mouthfilling. Superior and pleasant.

Bottled. Pours clear, golden with a white head. Fair lacings. Nose of citrus and flowerish hops. Medium sweet flavour with light malt, honey, grass and citrus, flowers and light fruits. Light to medium bodied. Crisp and very enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle; thanks to beernbourbon for the trade; glowing orange with frothy white head fading quickly; sweet honey, wheat, lemons and a big does of grassy hops; raw lemons and sweet malt with thin body and almost sweet syrupy texture; pretty interesting and one Id like to try again sometime
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are yeast, hops, elderflower, perfume and malt.

Pours hazy yellow, Very fresh citrus aroma. very hopy. Lemons, fresh lemons. Great flavour, fruit and banana, lemon to start followed by deep hop complexity. This kicks ass.!!! This is how I wish all wheat ale was. Hopy and kick ass. citrus and complex.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear golden - white head. Nice hoppy aroma, citrus, pineapples, grassy, piney, taste: light caramel, wheaty, fruity, light bitterness, grassy, peppery.  Nice.

Bottle courtesy of a good friend. Golden pour with small head. Aroma of heavy grapefruit rind, sugar, and wheat. Flavor is more bitter than would be expected. Bread, grass, pine and wheat. Slight malty finish. Dryish. Nice

"Honey colored pour, 1/2" foamy white head and grand lacing. Mostly grapefruit and lemon in the nose due to a ton of aroma hops, a nice grassy wheat scent is also present. Light to medium bodied, exceptionally dry and crisp. Its lighter and more balanced than expected, and this creates for a really great session beer. Grassy, dry wheat. Fresh hops providing lots of citrus notes followed by some biscuits. Tap hop flavor compared to the aroma and the bitterness is moderate. First class session wheat....nothing over the top just great from start to finish."

33cl bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. The pour is bubbly and crystal clear golden with a neat white foamy head that fades a little. The aroma is nice pale-ale like with fresh hoppy notes that brings you back to the piny woods of sweden on a wet day in spring. Some citric and malty backing with a small metallic impression - quite alot of nose when talking about a wheat beer. The mouthfeel is surprisingly thick with a mild oily palate. The taste is yummy and the taste of malts along with some citrus makes it both fresh and very easy to drink. The finish is mild with a malty attitude that leaves some metallic and bitter impressions along the way. Good beer for a wheat.

Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Yellow colour. Light malty and moderate hoppy aroma. No wheat detected. Moderate bitter grassy lavor. Average moderate bitter inish. Oily palate. Disapointing.

courtesy of thetomg, thank you! pours crisp gold with a minimal head. aroma is like a wheat with a lemon in it, super citrusy and resfrshing, and that goes for the drinking of it as well. good stuff, nice session beer from fff.

Wow..this is something new and noteworthy.  I know that FFF gets a lot of love (and after DLD 10 a lot of hate), but this beer is original and tasty.  A nice citrusy aroma following by a relatively solid wheat beer with a big wallop of lemony hops on the back.  Ive never had anything like it and I like it!

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 Pours up with a nice thick head with staying power.  The beer is fairly cloudy with tiny particles suspended in it and has a distinct aroma of grapefruit - once you know what it is.  The flavor is very smooth and the only bite presents as citrus.  This beer will always have a special place in my heart as one of my early craft favorites.  Part of its unique history is falling in love with it all over again once I found out the flavor was grapefruit, which I do not like.  I loved it before I knew, and I appreciate it now.  Enjoyed another and wow does it go down smooth.

Bottle from StFun, Thanks Josh! Pours hazy yellow with frothy head. Aroma is surprisingly hoppy, with citrus and grapefruit all over. The hops come through beautifully in the flavor, yet the beer finishes with subtle wheat as well. Drinks more like a pale ale than wheat beer, but still a wonderful beer, must be perfect for a sunny day.

A- Body is a nearly transparent blonde that pours with an approximately 2 finger white head. Head fades pretty quickly to a thick collar but leaves some traces of lacing all the way down the glass.

S- First thing that comes to the nose is a big dose of citrus hops. There is a big sweet, bready yeast backbone and a touch of pine to go along with it.

T- Some grapefruit flavor upfront with a small amount of yeast backbone. The taste gets really interesting for the finish where a big grapefruit juice flavor comes through along with a distinct sweet wheat flavor, a touch of pine, and a touch of bitterness. What lingers is some Citrus hop resin, some grapefruit and other citrus flavor, and a touch of sweet yeast.

P- Medium to high carbonation and nice, light, very drinkable body. Pretty smooth.

O- This beer is awesome. I knew with how much I love UberSun that I would really like this. Ubersun, hopsun, and gumball head are all similar...but gumballhead seems to offer a similar punch to ubersun without the extra ABV associated. Im really happy I have 3 bottles of this!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-04-2008 22:06:58

Great beer! The hoppy wheat thing works perfectly here! Poured with a nice fine foamy frothy off white head and good lace. Color is a clear amber. Aroma is malty hoppy and fruity. Flavors similar. Body is excellent ditto carbonation. Finish is a tad sweet but very well balanced. Very drinkable. Session beer.

12 oz bottle from Casanova.  Straw colored pour with a fluffy white head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is actually hoppy and citrus/lemony.  Flavor is clean, somewhat hoppy and a bit citrusy.  Finish is smooth with a bit of lingering citrus.  Very unique for a wheat beer for me.
On tap at more and more Chicago area bars, had it at the mecca Brixies. Poured pale yellow, nice simple brew (does 3F do anything simple), little floral kick from the Amarillo. 3F does little wrong.

Bottle thanks to Spence.  Pours clear golden with really no haze at all and a modest bubbly white head.  Nose is definitely hoppy.  Big citric (mostly orange/tangerine) hops are the main deal here, with some minor lemon and not so much wheat.  Tastes a hell of a lot more like a hoppy pale ale to me, but what do I know?  Still good.  Nice and light and even better for being <5%.

Bottle, shared by NachalmSie. The aroma is sweet tangerine hops, and not much else. The flavor is the same, with lots of juicy tangerine and orange notes, and only slight wheaty graininess. This is basically a good American Pale Ale that happens to contain wheat.
Really solid wheat ale. One of the hoppier wheat ales Ive had, but Im ok with it. Nice malt backbone there too. Easy to drink and compliments food really well. Worth a try for sure.

Pours clear golden yellow with a white fizzy head that clings to the glass.  Floral, pine, and citrus aromas.  Orange blossoms come to mind.    Nice balance between the hops and malt.  Creamy mouthfeel with a medium to high level of carbonation.  Very drinkable beer.

Wow, this was an unexpected surprise!  Bought a 12oz bottle along with some Dreadnaught and Alpha King...figured I would break out the "lightweight" of the bunch as a mid-week snack.

Pours a clear straw gold with a perfect finger cap of bright white head, just enough to lace the glass while still letting tons of aroma through.  Nose is lemon, evergreen boughs, and fresh wheat.  Smells very crisp and enticing, and leads well into the flavors.  Taste is strongly peppery and fresh, with nice hop resin and heavy wheat malt.  Complex flavor for a session beer, and one of my new favorites!

Creamy mouthfeel and a crisp pepper finish.  Good to the last drop!
Pours a clear golden with thin white head. Aroma is a mix of spruce and citrus with an undertone of smoke. Flavor is a mix of floral citrus with spruce notes. Body is creamy with medium carbonation.

Draft @ Three Floyds, Munster, IN. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy citrus aroma. Fruityy wheat malty hoppy citrus flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty hoppy citrus finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 Pours straw gold, slightly hazy, with foamy white head leaving a lot of lacing.  High carbonation.  Aroma is grapefruit with a little lemon and pepper.  Very light and refreshing.  Wheat, lemon, and hops.  With the aroma on this one, I guess I was expecting quite a different taste.  Not a bad brew just lacking the impact I have come to expect from 3Fs brews.

Re-rate (3/29/2013):  First time I have had this fresh, believe it or not.  Usually cant count on whats on the shelf, but now that there is a lot of turnover of the product at my local liquor store...lets go!  Much fresher hop aroma with more of a sweet, floral pine and wheat malt aroma.  Flavor is wheat malt sweetness with light pine and citrus bitterness trailing to a lightly bitter and dry finish.  Funny how perceptions change after diving further into craft beer.  Regardless, better fresh. +2

Pours Light golden  with a thin white head....Aroma exceeds appearance  with strong hops,pine,and citrus wiffs......taste clean, floral and astringent   lot of  hop ......piney  small buble that burst along the tounge nicely not over carbonated lightly sour, medium sweetness,
its not Normal  but it sure is prefered.

A: The pour on this beer is quite unassuming. A pale golden color with a small white foam that dissipates quickly to a thin layer. The lacing, however, is quite nice.

S: Things start to get much better in the aroma. A nice, bright citrus hop aroma with a fair amount of pine to go along with it. Not much malt or wheat to speak of in the nose.

T: Like the nose would indicate, a solid hop presence. The grapefruit is front and center with a mild pine on the finish. The malt and wheat provide a bit of sweetness in the middle of the tongue.

M: A light, crisp beer with fairly high carbonation.

D: This would be a nice one for the summer months. A refreshing beer, no doubt, and low alcohol would make this a staple in my fridge (could I easily attain it).

The aromas of this beer convinced my brother, strictly gluten-free, to break his diet for it.  Worth it?  I dont know, but this really is pretty excellent.  Pours surprisingly dark - a medium amber - and clear for a bottle-conditioned wheat beer.  Very little head.  Aromas of summer fruits - apricot and muscat grape - leap off the glass, and upon sipping floral hop aromas predominate.  This gives way to an almost IPA-like impression, a fairly malty flavor balanced by very American hops.  This is a hop-lovers wheat; the aromas are complex and magnificent.  But they do not overpower; the tastes of fruit and malt weave in and out of the swiftly-departing bitterness, creating a cohesive and melodious whole.  A superb wheat beer.
smells of hops wheat and watermellon tastes good and hoppy with wheat to start and watermellon to finish very good wheat beer

Bottle pours a clear golden yellow with a very thin white head that dissipates quickly.   Im surprised by the high clarity of this beer since it is a bottle conditioned wheat beer.  Aroma is floral and fruity.  Taste starts out sweet and malty with the wheat base but then assaults your palate with a lemon and grapefruit bitter finish.  Light to medium body and carbonation.  While this is probably the most aggressively hopped wheat beers Ive had, it also is like the best one Ive had.

12 oz. bottle
sweet hoppy aroma
hoppy sweet taste with a slight lemony twang
excellent
Great summer beer - a ligher and very hoppy wheat beer. Disadvantage, it is only sold in the midwest - Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin.

Nice clear orange body with heavy carbonation. Faint white head that left a tiny ring after ten minutes. Sweet floral hop notes with not a hint o wheat. Hops and sweet malt flavors preceded a grainy finish.

Pours light golden amber with a white head.  Aroma is a combination of citrusy and minty hops and a little bit of spice.  Flavor is nice blend of malted wheat, with citrus, mint, and hints of spice.  Great wheat beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy gold, with a thin off-white head that diminished quickly.  Aromas of lemon zest, faint cinnamon, dough, basil, pine.  The taste is slightly sweet with a nice lemony bitterness, slightly watery.  The finish is bitter metallic, with some citrus (grapefruit).  The wheat is there, and its nice to taste it through the hops for a change.  As far as hoppy beers go, this is pretty easy drinking.

From a trade with my beer friend at the LCBO, thanks buddy, hope you enjoy your stone russian imp stout! Cheers!
Pours a hazy gold colour with a two finger heads that disolves down to a thin film, leaves behind some nice lacing. The aroma is very hop forward, reminds me of a bit of southern tiers IPA, but a with a welcome element from the wheat. The flavour is also very hopped up, citrus, alot of lemon flavour in this beer, I agree with most when they say the hops are a little muted by the wheat, but im thinking this was intentional, if it was just straight up hoppy, itd be an IPA. The wheat does bring some flavour to the party, but its a little shy when held up against the life of the party (the hops), not exactly balanced, I agree with thirdeye, it could use a little malt backbone. Mouthfeel is a little thing, but I think the idea of this beer is flavour in harmony with drinkability, and they achieved that.  I enjoyed this beer, not really my thing, but still delicious.

12oz bottle poured into a wheat beer glass produced a cloudy orange body with thin white head.  Typical wheat beer appearance.  Aroma of lemons.  Taste dominated by citrus notes of grapefruit, oranges, and lemons.

Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Aroma is dominated by fruit, specifically grapefruit, with small hints of pine. Taste is of grapefruit and oranges. This beer seems like more of an ale than a wheat beer. Drinks nice, but a bitter aftertaste. Not what I expected, but good none the less.

Bottle - Pours clear and amber with a small white head. Aroma is a ridiculous blast of hops, all resiny and citrusy, with grapefruit being the predominant smell. Theres a hint of grassiness in there too, but not much else. Its not complex, but thats okay--it smells delicious. The taste is interesting, kind of like NG Crackd Wheat, where youve got that APA/hefe hybrid. It falls a little short of CW, however, in that the two seem out of balance. The wheat overpowers the hops and really mute out the grapefruit, and the whole thing leaves a sour, funky finish and aftertaste. Its pretty light, though a bit syrupy. I could drink a 100 of these if not for the aftertaste and accompanying breath that would knock a moose over.

(bottle) Pours a slightly hazy, but mostly clear light gold with a medium white head that sticks around.  Aroma is full of fresh citric hoppiness, with some grapefruit, lemon peel, and a subtle earthiness.  Further sniffs reveal some cheerios, mint, celery, and orange marmalade.  Taste has flavors of watered-down orange juice, some guava, and finishes out with flavors of breakfast cereal and orange marmalade.  In-between the orange and cereal is a brief hit of bitter hops that provides a nice tea-like astringency.  Aside from the nose, nothing really stands out here.  Might be a decent summer beer, but other than that, this is pretty disappointing.

( 12oz bottle) Pours a very pale color, but the head is amazing, huge bubbles in it, 2 fingers, and lots of carbonation coming from the bottom of this one. No lacing really. Smell is pretty straightforward. Grapefruit galore. In fact Ive never smelled a beer anything quite like this. Its good, refreshing, and straight up grapefruit. Not complex but solid. Maybe some spices here too. Taste is muted grapefruit compared to the smell. Its a wheaty beer compared to how pale and clear this one is, but it is a little fruity, definitely spicy, and nicely refreshing. Hops are present here too and nicely done. Could use a bit more malt backbone to balance out the hops and spices though. Needs more creaminess, carbonation is nice.

12oz bottle.  A yellow orange color with a sweet grapefruit cherry aroma and some pine.  A crisp refreshing start with a bready hop finish.  This is more like an ale then a wheat beer.  A great session brew for outdoor drinking only.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2016 Sixer from Old Town dated 11/30/16. Aroma: Light wheat and floral/botanicals with juicy peach. Appearance: Rich gold filtered body with a mesmerizing stream of slow, but constant carbonation holding up a sticky white head that settles, but never fades entirely. Flavor: Light wheat with floral/botanical notes initially; juicy peach takes over and is finally quenched by a light, drying pleasant bitterness. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, lively carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: This earns a five from me due to a) Its a beer that, when consumed, immediately makes me want another, and b) leaves me speechless with regards to what could be improved or changed. Worthy of the highest commendations.

It pours bright wheat straw in appearance with a big beautiful white head. With a lemony aroma, the beer first tastes like a delicius thick wheat beer and finishes perfectly with a cascade of sweet hops that delight the palate. The end reminds me of the smoothness of the hop slam.
One of my favorite drinking beers. Refreshing, light, but complex enough to keep you interested. Citrus, bubblegum, with a little bitterness and lemon in the finish.

12.28.09 bottle.  Pours hazy amber with off-white medium bodied head.  Aroma is citrusy, grapefruit, slight bitterness, hoppy.  Tastes full-bodied hoppiness, citrus, tart, slight bitterness.  Very nice beer.  Dry mouth feel.
Too light. But that lemony hoppy flavor comes straight through - and it is delicious - balanced out well with the sweet and spicy wheat essence. Excellent beer to drink, uh, quickly.
draft: golden amber with a foamy white head, hoppy, grassy aroma and a mild hoppy, grassy taste, slight bitterness in the finish, very nice
Dark orange, almost pinkish with a sticky white foam.  Aroma is spicy, hoppy, light wheat.  Taste is spicy again, piney hops, light malt sweetness, full body wheat.

Bottle at Timothy OTooles, Chicago. Came in an awesome bottle, like everything they make. Pours a very light yellow, almost no head (what head there was dissipated quickly and left an unfortunate film on top). Wheat ale? Really? This was one of the most straight-forward aggressive hop-fests Ive had in awhile, and considering that my most recent ratings were Double Bastard, 120 Minute, and Ruination, thats saying something. Id put it closest to Ruination, as there is almost no malty flavor to offset the hoppiness. Its decidedly uncomplex--very clear taste, cuts like a laser, and it goes down easily. Overall, enjoyable enough that I ordered two.

Bottle. Light yellow-orange in color and totally clear with a small off-white head. Aroma brings citrusy hops and some pine, as well as a little bit of wheat. Citrus hops are dominant in the flavor from start to finish, with a little spicy wheat in the background. Carbonation is a little sharp for my liking. Not a bad brew, but it doesnt suit my tastes entirely.

12 oz bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a medium sized white head. Extremely nice hop character for a wheat beer. Good citrus flavors, pine, grapefruit.  I am still amazed about how the beer is so much more hoppy than any wheat beer Im used to. Fantastic!
Poured clear golden, pineapple, wheat, citrus hops, caramel, little spice, little bready.

A: Golden yellow in color with a solid one finger head. The head dies to a nice ring and left behind nice thin sheets of lace.

S: The hoptastic aroma is what always brings me back to this one. Nice citrus hops with light touches of sweet pine and earthy green grass notes.

T: Your typical wheat beer this is not. The taste of bold citrus hops is what this one is all about. It has the taste of a piece of fresh Florida grapefruit with a nice piney sweetness in the finish. This beer like most from 3 Floyds is VERY aggressive for the style. This aggressiveness is what put them in a class of their own to us loyal following of HopHeads.

M: Nice crisp carbonation very smooth.

Got 3 bottles of this in a trade. Hazy and pale yellow pour with a pretty thick white coating of head that is long lasting and leaves big sticky icky lacing on the glass. Aroma was much hoppier than I was anticipating, in fact the main smell was of citrus fruit like pineapples and apricots, some wheat in there as well but more in the back. Flavor was slightly more prominently wheat, but also had a ton of tropical fruit flavor, with the pineapple and apricot and a lot of grapefruit as well. If this is truly a wheat ale than its the best one Ive ever had, but it tastes far from a wheat beer to these taste buds.

Bottle - pours a dark gold, mostly clear not cloudy.  Aroma of pine, slight lemon, grass, something unique I cannot quite classify. Moderate white head, mostly diminishing, with lacing throughout finish.  This is unlike any other "wheat" ale I have ever tasted, definitely the hoppiest.  I really, really like it and the spices are pleasant to my palate, at least.  I can drink these all night - an excellent session beer for sure.  Well-balanced, and like I said to me the hop presence is excellent and welcomed with this beer.  The finish is smooth, tasty and not dry.  Cheers!

Bottle.  Pours a hazy body with a white head.  Wheat notes; citrus, coriander, lemon grass, and pepper notes.  Spicy hints of ginger and pepper tones.  Sweet and slightly chewy with a light fruit y finish.  Good brew.

Pours the typical cloudy orange you might expect of a wheat ale.  Little less orange though.  Maybe not very much wheat in the mash?  Anyways, aroma of piney hops without much of cloves or bananas you might expect of a wheat beer.  Flavor is certainly more pronounced in terms of hops than any wheat I know of.  However, I do pick out the typical banana flavors more here than in the aroma.  Finishes nice and yeasty.  Definitely a good beer that is pretty sessionable.

Bottle from a trade with StFun. Pours dark hazy golden color with off white head. Really strong hoppy aroma for a wheat beer. Lots of lemon and grapefruit. Flavor is also very citrusy with grapfruit dominating and some wheat. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Not a typical wheat beer but very good nonetheless. Thanks Josh.
Love all three floyds beer, as they are a local brewery that takes pride in every beer they produce!

Picked up a sixer at a place called Hi-way liquor about 35 miles outside Indianapolis (looking for any Three Floyds products, especially Dark Lord). Copper blonde pour into off-white foamy head that dissipates into sticky melting lacing as carbonated bubbles rise from the bottom of the glass into a swirling pool of bubbly foam. Aroma of piney hops and sweet malty biscuit. Initial flavor of wheat bread that slowly fades into a lemony grapefruit citrus finish with hint of sugary candy.

Bottle - Poured clear golden color with minimal white head.
Aroma - Initial citrus grassy hop scent followed by bread and slight barnyard smell.
Flavor - Citrus and bread like taste, bitter and also tasted like rye. Really enjoyed the nice hop bite!!
Palate - Medium bodied and sticky texture. Average carbonation and finish is bitter and fairly long.
Overall - Pretty good brew. Too high priced for a low ABV. and taste is just above average!!

Bottle. Smell is sweet, hoppy, fresh, piney, peppery, licorice-y. Bit of that licorice and pine continues in the tasting ... bready, little thin, metallic, and I suppose, a bit of bubblegum. Bitter. Not like any other wheat beer Ive had.

A hoppy wheat beer? Its great. Pours light amber with a thick white head and sticky lacing. The aroma is immediately noticeable with spice, pine, and of course glorious hops. The palate is fairly light with lower carbonation, and the flavor isnt too bitter. Some wheat and malt definitely shines through although the hops overwhelm the wheat a bit. However, Im not complaining about that too much.

Bottle shared @ the HotD dock sale [thanks guyinchicago for the trade!]...  Poured hay golden with a white head.  Hops and wheat on the nose.  Floral hops and spiced.  Light refreshing, earthy and fruits.  Lemon-citrus and creamy finish.

Pours a pale gold color with a disappearing white head. The aroma is very light, with notes of  dough, banana, berries, and caramel. The flavor is fruity and slightly sweet with berries and flowery hops in the background. Notes of tart fruit settle in the middle with a nice grainy, bready, mildly hoppy finish. For a wheat ale, this is very good. But I can think of several pale ales that taste very similar and are probably more enjoyable.
Bottle Pour at the Onion Pub in Barrington, Illinois.  pours golden with great citrus notes and notes of flowers.  Drinks with heavy citrus notes and a nice easy finish for a wheat.

From the bottle, pours a clear golden yellow with a thin white head.  Citrus and floral hops are the aroma.  Piney, grassy hops, lightly bitter finish.  This drinks much more like a pale ale than a wheat. Light and drinkable, a pretty good pale ale.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 It is always a treat to sample something I have not yet had from Three Floyds.  This has a funny drawing on the label of a comic book character.  Interesting pour - dark gold, with an almost rosy hue.  It has a surprisingly hoppy aroma for a wheat brew, with lots of sweet floral scent from the aroma masters at 3F.  It tastes really good too - as much like a fine pale ale as a wheat, with a crisp, grapefruit nip to it. There is also a touch of strawberry or some other kind of fruit.  Light bodied, but still full flavored.  This belongs with Alpha King as the best moderately priced, everyday beers in America.  Gumballhead is another unique and amazing creation from Three Floyds.  Loses a bit of flavor if you hang onto it, so my advice is drink it up and enjoy!
Cloudy golden pour from bottle.  Citrus on the nose, tart, yet pleasing on the palate.  Satin smooth finish.  Very drinkable, and a great year around beer.

bottle, pours a deep hazy gold, thin white head.  Pine resin and citrus hop nose with hints of lemon peel.  Nice soft wheat and pale malt body with a bitter lemon and hop finish that is very pale ale in nature.  Dry, mildly piney, but with a pronounced hop bite that keeps things refreshing.  Nice!

Slightly hazy gold, only a scant white head, but it nonetheless manages a decent lacing. Strong, floral-sweet hops aroma, a bit of peppermint to it. Flavor similarly dominated by the floral hops presence, partially offset by a cellary yeast must, some whole-grain huskiness on the finish. Medium body, zesty with a thickness in the finish.

Bottle courtesy of Davinci. Slight haze on the straw colored pour, aromas of slightly tart lemons and a bit of wheat with an over-riding rapefruit and pine hopppiness that was pretty unexpected. Flavor is, in short, the wonderfulness of the aroma  - the earthy, lemon/melon wheat softens the huge dose of piney hops that finish this one. A lovely summer beer that I would drink year round were it here in CO. Awesome stuff. THanks, Beejay.

On tap at The Rotten Apple.  A wheat ale that finishes almost like an IPA.  Quite tart throughout with edges smoothed out by the wheat.  Plenty of citrus in both the nose and flavor that includes lemon.  A fine beer by any standard.

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a small white head. Nice lacing. Strong aroma of pine and citrus, with a bit of wheat. Flavor is sweet with lots of pine and citric hops on the finish. Although there is a touch of malt, somehow comes off well balanced. A hop lovers wheat dream.

9/28/09 notes: poured at GABF session two.  What stuck out in my mind is the interesting sour-grapefruit twang this beer possessed.  It was definitely there, along with wheat and some cloves.  Balanced, rounded body, with a grainy and satisfying juicy hop finish.  Id like to try a bottle of this, since the complexity of the wheat ale surprised me.

Bottle thanks to Bulldogp04! Pours a murky orange with a decent head. Lovely aroma of tropical fruits, and a good deal of hop aroma as well. Flavor is damn tasty. Citrus, tropical fruits such as mango and a hint of pineapple..some lemon zest, and some piney hops. Fantastic beer.

Bottle thanks to Bman1113VR who was my secret santa this summer. Pours a just hazy browned apricot color with a medium to large bone white head. Nice hoppy citrus and mango notes, deceptive at first since I didnt bother to read anything on the bottle to know that this was hopped so heavily, and my first reaction was that theyd gotten a label wrong.  Really nice hop presence with some faint wheat behind it.  Good mouthfeel, lemony and with some gentle wheat.  Really tasty.  Finishes on the dry side with a little subtle grapefruit bitterness.  Im impressed.  Not at all what I was expecting, but still really nice.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2009 Appearance:  Pours a cloudy, yellow gold with only a small gathering of white head.

Aroma:  Citrus, fresh saw dust, and sweet grain.

Taste:  Light fruit, and a decent amount of husky grain, finishing with some nice spicy bitter hops. The hopping isnt overwhelming, but its there.

Mouthfeel:  Thin and fizzy. This is deceptive when you look at this cloudy beer, you think its going to be quite thick.

Overall: A fantastic, charismatic beer. I think I could drink many of these in a session.
Hazy gold. Small, frothy, off white head. Nose is wheat and hops, grainy, piney, and citrusy. Smells like a wheat pale ale. Not much to this one.

Appearance was quite grand, you usually have to have a phenominal head to get this high of a score from me but the insane amount of carbonation presence is something I see. The head is white and a thin crown with good lacing. The liquid is a very light gold. 

Scent is an interesting lemony and hoppy concoction. I noticed a bready scent when I opened the bottle but no longer pin that down. 

Taste, while I cant complain that it isnt pleasant or refreshing, I struggle to detect anything as it isnpretty subdued. Same characteristics as the scent. This would be a hell of an intro to craft. 

Mouth is where of needs to be, thin/med and fizzy. 

Very east to drink and I want to try more to male sure my palate isnt fooling me into thinking this is weaker than it really is.

Draft from 14 West in downtown Indianapolis.  Pours a clear but slightly hazy gold with a bit of reddish orange tint and a medium white head.  Pleasant, light aroma of citrus, hops, melon, and wheat.  Flavor is more of the same, and the hops really pop on the palate.  Smooth, sweet, perfectly balanced with a light-medium mouthfeel that I enjoy so much I find myself drinking it too fast so I can keep repeating the experience.  I absolutely love this beer and cant imagine anyone disliking it.  Three Floyds hits yet another home run.

It looks normal, all hazy with a slight orange tinge after the pour, but that is quickly dispelled.  The citrus/floral hop hit your nose receives upon the first sniff serves as an indication that this wheat ale is not normal.  A sip confirms, this is a hop monster of a wheat ale.  Ive witnessed its addictive qualities on craftbrew neophytes.  It can satisy a hopheads jones, or it is perfect for summer sessions.
