No need to compromise on your summer beer- you get the wheat, lemon and light body with a juicy hop blast. Some spicyness on the tongue and banana in the nose make the finish on this one memorable. No lawn mowers here.
Hazy golden with a big white head. Has a very surprising hop aroma, american hop aroma. Lemon, guava and grapefruit with some wheaty accents. Flavour of wheat and lemon with a hoppy citric finish.

Botttle @ Oliver Twist, StockholmBacklog 23 Aug 2004Probably my first american wheat. Not impressed at all. Hoppy aroma (dont like that in a wheatbeer). No body and hardly any aftertaste. Odd sweet side tones in the aftertaste as well.

Neat beer.  Pours a light misty orange.  Sufficiently cloddy to remind you that its a wheat.  Aroma is sharp and tangy- citrus hops, lemon and grapefruit.  The flavor is pretty sharp and bitter upfront, fades to hops and finishes pretty flat, like a standard wheat beer.  Quite pleasent.  Not outstanding in any way, aside from originality maybe,  but I really enjoy drinking it.

Slightly hazy, dark gold. Small white head. Good lace. Big, fresh, hoppy aroma. Medium, slightly grainy feel. Big, hoppy flavour of pine & citrus w/ some very faint wheaty undertones. Wheat Beer? I would have guessed an IPA.

pours a pretty yellow/gold, lightly hazy, very well-carbonated with a long lasting white head. nose is full of amarillo hops, with their charecteristic citric, almost tangerine nose. beer drinks like an IPA-a hop drenched flavor with a light tang from the wheat. beer is nicely dry, with a light and lively palate. a unique beer.

West coast hoppiness, golden amber, small off-white head. Quite hoppy and a malt follow up. Medium bodied, hoppy. Very nice beer, doesn't seem to fit the style.

 Thanks joey_capps.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2005 pale yellow color, totally clear, with smallish white head. Aroma is absolutely full of amarillo hops, slightly spicey. Flavor is hoppy, sweet, a touch of wheat, rather acidic. A nice summery brew, kind of like a super hoppy american pilsner. Although I love amarillo hops, this brew may overdo it a bit. Its still good.

Bottled. Hazy deep golden, brief heead. Bubblegum aroma.. Sweetish up front with loads of aromatic hops. Soft but clean mouthfeel. Refreshing with salrt, fairly bitter finish. A wheat beer hopped to hell, which is a good thing when talking about American wheats...
Golden beer with a pleasant tangerine aroma, almost like perfume. Good malt and pleasant citrusy hops, with resinous overtones, Medium bodied. Excellent!
Pours yellow with a large head--looks like a wheat beer should. Great aroma of wheat and hops and an excellent wheat/citrus flavor. A good beer.

Slightly hazy yellow/gold body with a big fluffy white head and decent lacing.  Starts with citrus and hop aromas, I tried and tried but didnt smell any bubblegum - still this has a great aroma.  Body is thin and full of a wheaty tang followed by a juicy citrus hop - oh yeah, its amarillo - I luv amarillo hops!

Bottle. Medium sized white head and fne-medium sized bubbles that mostly diminished. Carbonated, transparent and a yellow gold hue. Aroma was sweet and very hoppy. Flavor was hoppy, hoppy, hoppy. Palate was hoppy. Fair lacing.

Hazy golden color with a large white head. The aroma was full of citrus...particularly grapefruit, with a sweet character in the background...bubblegum, ashes, and toasted wheat. The flavor was wonderfully balanced between the aggressive citrus hop tones and the sweeter wheat tones. Lively, crisp feel with a semi-dry finish. Wonderful American Wheat! Thanks BBB63.
Lightly hazy pale yellow color with a large white head. Strong grapefruit hops and bubblegum aroma. Nice crisp grapefruit hops, lemon, malt and bubblegum flavors. A great summer session beer!

The beer came is a 22 oz. brown bomber with no freshness date.  The body of the pour was hazy pale yellow with a tall creamy head.  The aroma was very flowery hops with a touch of citrus.  The taste was refreshingly hoppy and citric with a sweet fruity malt undertone.  The mouthfeel was slick and soft with a perfect carbonation.  Aftertaste was a bit drying after each swallow, causing you to rush to the next sip.  A perfect summer session brew that melds the best aspects of a wheat beer and an IPA.

Golden yellow clear beer under a thick white head that gives off a bready aroma with just a touch of hops.
Light malt flavor with just  enough hop bitterness towards the end to  balance out some of the sweetness.
This misses a lot of the characteristics of a Wheat beer, but it would do well as a good Pale Ale.
Pours a hazy yellow/orange. Strong aromas of grapefruit, oranges and pine. Very light body, with lots of grapefruit and orange flavors. Smooth finish, with some hop bitterness in the end.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2006 Super hoppy American wheat.  Fizzy with little head.  Grapefruit taste.  High price and low alcohol content.  Poor wheat character, but tastes okay.  Not bad, but nothing special; given the inflated price.  Looks pretty though.

Light orange gold color. Medium sized white head. Aroma is fruity, sweet and orange. A medium bodied wheat beer. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hints of orange and citrus, with slightly bitter hops. Nicely balanced. Crisp clean flavors. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2004 Dark straw colored brew. Great nose with a little hoppiness and a little lemon citrus. Light/medium body with a slight herbal hoppiness at the front. Finishes tart and clean. Really enjoyable and different wheat.Forgot to thank jcalabre and hopsrus for this one!

22 oz bottle.  Lightly hazy medium amber, medium-to-large stable head.  Nose big on sour lemon, hops and honey..quite powerful if fairly simple.  On the tongue, hoppy and slightly citrusy at the front, sweet honey in the middle and a nice toasty caramel-bready malt backbone present near the relatively dry finish.  Certainly top-notch for this bastardized style, refreshing and very clean, something Id probably drink regularly if I had access...but comes off closer to a pale ale than a wheat to my tastebuds.
Bottle @ RBSG 04 Grand TastingAroma is full of hops, Belgian yeast character & citrus watermelon. The flavor is smooth with lots of hops. Clean, balanced. Tasty!

Golden slightly hazy body topped with a this white head.  Quite a bit of flowery hops with a touch of citrus in the nose, and not much else.  Flavors are well balanced.  I picked up some flower/grass from the hops and a little touch of lemon.  Not real big on the wheat flavors, but pleasing.  Dry, spicy finish.  Kinda like a cross between an APA and an American Wheat.  Unique and pleasing.

Hazy deep gold w/ little to no white head.  initial aroma is of raw, grassy hops.  Hops, hops, hops.. grassy & herbal.  Beyond that there is a little wheat malt, and only hints of lemon citrus hop as it warms.  Flavor is pretty much the same, grassy & herbal.  Well balanced, but hop flavored;  Lightly spicy hop, wheat malt.  Finish is a little dry and woody, aftertaste is bland & hop flavored.  Lightly astringent, lighter body, higher carbonation.  Not sure what they were trying to accomplish w/ this beer, but it doesnt have any real identity but hops!  Not crisp & refreshing as a wheat should be, and has too much hop flavor for anything but a one dimensional beer.

Golden effervescent body with small white head.  Unique strong hoppy(citrus), sweet yeasty aroma with a bit of spiciness.  The flavor starts out hoppy and bitter and finsihes the same way.  Along the way  there is a modest lemon flavoring with a faint yeastiness.  This is an excellent, unique(at least to my current knowledge) and enjoyable brew, but it does seem to be a little too original.
Nose of citrus and lemon zest.  Great hop bitterness throughout with a great flavor from the Amarillo hops.  A very enjoyable summer brew.
22ouncer.  Great hoppy aroma, wonderful refreshing taste with a mix of wheat and hop flavor.  Damn good.

Bottle.  Looks like a normal wheat beer, but it comes out as being overly hoppy in the aroma.  An interesting take on the style; sometimes poorly made hefes taste like bubblegum.  They apparently did it on purpose and hopped the shit out of it!  The aroma IS nice, but the hops and wheat just dont match up in the flavor very well for me and this is stuck in the realm of the mediocre, especially compared with the other great 3F offerings.

Sampled on tap at Brewtopia 04. Golden color with very little head. Aroma
of citrus and hops. Hops and lemon are
the predominate flavors. Not like any wheat beer Ive ever had. Extremely
refreshing. I wish FFF were available
on the East coast.
Gold wiith a light head and spotty lacing. Very sprucy aromas. Some citrus and a nice malt backing. Malt flavors, more spruce, wheat or malts and some bitter hops. Nice malt palate and damn smooth

Its been some time since Ive had this so Im going on memory.  I recall it being surprisingly good.  A hoppy wheat beer which is in itself a rarity although this was also well done.  The perfect copmpliment to a hot summer day although drinkable year round.   Quite lemony in a good way complimented with a balanced bitterness.  Highly recommend it.
RBSG 04. Pours a light orange/golden color witha small white head. Great citrus hop aroma. Taste is very hoppy but balances the wheaty malt with a nice controlled bitterness.

22 ounce bomber.  an agressive wheat but what else would you expect from three floyds.  the citrus hop taste is amazing.  highly recommended.  dont be intimidated by the bomber it will leave you wanting more.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2004 On tap at Map Room in Chicago...Amazed by this beer wonderful flavor and aroma, ok color, not like any wheat Ive ever had, and even though all wheats are not the same...this stuff is just plain left field....love the hops on this and yes it does quench your thirst like a summer beer should

sampled at RBSG 04. 
pours golden, has a tangy flavor. its a very mild wheat.

Pours hazy yellow/golden with not much of a head. Little lemon thingies floating in the beer look like sea monkeys. Initial taste is hops and citrus. This beer tastes like an IPA with lemons. Different than anything Ive had before, and I must say I enjoyed it. I look forward to trying other FFF stuff.

Looked like atypical wheat beer...hazy straw color with small white head.  Nice armoma, sorta lemony.  Hop flavor seems to stand out at the beginning and then finishes like drinking lemon peels.  While I am not a fan of wheat beers this is one of the better wheat beers I have ever had.
Instead of the label-predicted lemon, I found grapefruit.  Very tart.  herbal (almost grassy) aroma with a bit of spice.

Sampled at From The Vine beer tasting Jul 9th, 2004: This beer definitely stretches the definition of the style, but Ill be damned if it isnt one of the best Wheat beers I have ever had. I consider myself a comic book fan yet I have never heard of Mr. Gumballhead, but I like his style! The beer is a golden yellow color with nice effervescence. The head is medium thin milky white and lasting. Nice aroma of floral hops, wheat and a touch of citrus. Light-bodied and very easy to drink, with less hops in the flavor than in the nose but still a great amount. There is also a nice wheat presence along with some lemon and grass. Overall, the wheat overlaid with the hops texture makes this pretty close to the perfect summer beer for me. A bomber of this will disappear before you know it.
Golden color, nice amount of carbonation, lots of orange citrus notes here. I love Amarillo hops, and now I love them in American Wheat beers! Light and quenching and delicious.

Bottle: good nose, I get a citrus pine combo, more orange on the nose. orange yellow color. small head. well carbonated though. sweet bitter flavors. orange and grapefruit. bitter finish, thinner body. Very tasty. Different than any wheat I've had before. Why isnt this an IPA?  Had on draft at Brewtopia. Score would be 8/3/8/3/17
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: this shit reeks of hops.  almost smells like an india pale.  pour is dark yellow with a small white head left.  taste is pleasing but pretty grassy.  like the labels say, this sure isnt normal.  this is no where near what i would expect an american wheat to be.  ill drink it sure, but even though its a FFF i feel like its not something i would buy again.  taste is just not very pleasing to me.  note- the more i drank of this, the more i enjoyed it, but my rating is still the same.  this is good but its not FFF good...

Speckled light pumpkin. Cakey ring surrounds a broken foam layer. Aromatic hop nose loaded with orange marmalade and candied pineapple. Soft peachy esters, herbs, and lightly toasted malts. Brisk, expansive carbonation, slowly turning creamy. Boisterous hop flavors flood the palate with rich peach and mandarin orange. Tasty subtleties of caramel, hop leaves, and perfume. Minimal hop bitterness in comparison to the bright, juicy hoppiness. Noticeably sweet and malty. Minty aspects continually highlight the remarkable freshness of the hops. Stupendously balanced toasted malt/citrusy hop interplay in the finish. Bright floral notes and late-merging sweet peach afterthoughts followed up with inevitable fresh-tasting hop belches from the extensive dry-hopping. Although it has that hallmark (alluring, but redundant) FFFs hop blend, its still undeniably tasty.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Surprisingly, this did not taste much like a wheat beer at all, but rather a pale ale.  The hops really come through in this beer and make for an interesting approach to the style.

Straw and lemon grass initially in the aroma, soon to compete with a citrusy, hoppy  nose.  Had only a slight wheat haze in the golden yellow appearance (I guess "red wheat" has no effect  on the color).  Moderately bitter, medium-bodied flavor, with a pronounced  hop presence.  Forget any comparison to a German weisen.   Dry, spicy finish.

Cloudy amber-orange color with a huge creamy head that leaves a thick sticky lacing in my glass. Hoppy aroma of grapefruits and candy, flavors of pine and citrus, never had a wheat beer taste like this before. Medium body with a somewhat sticky mouthfeel, finishes bitter.

22oz bottle  Murky golden/orange, white head.  Big dry-hopped aroma...fresh PNW citric, peachy hops.  Drinks light and easy.  Hops are big, but I dont get a lot of bitterness, a wheaty tart finish, but the hops do dominate this beer.  Overall, a nice spin on an otherwise boring style.  Thanks to jsquire for sending me this brew!

You gotta love the USA.  I love how American style means bigger, bolder, and usually better!  This American style wheat is one fantastic brew.  Since Ive started homebrewing, Amarillo hops have become my favorite.  I love those citrus aromas and what a blast of hop flavor.  This is one of my all time favorite wheat beers.

Not sure how they call this a "wheat" beer?  I didnt get any wheat since I was pelted by the hops.  Dont get me wrong, it was quite good, and certainly a differnt take on a wheat.  The aroma was strongly citrus, and the hops dominate throughout, with just a hint of sourness.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2011 Strong hop aroma.  However, it almost disappeared in the flavor.  Not completely, but its kinda disappointing.  The flavor is very smooth.  A highly drinkable and very refreshing brew.  If it was cheaper, instead of $5.99 for 22oz, Id buy this all the time.  As a wheat beer, its not really to style.  But as a beer, as it tastes, I dont mind drinking it.

This one was a somewhat shocker/volatile brew. At first, I was unimpressed. The more I sucked on it, the more I liked it. The taste alternated between malts and hops, ultimately balancing itself out in the end.  It was a deeper gold color, smelling quite citric and wheaty at the same time. Taste is actually very malty, compared to what I expected. Im so glad that I live in Chicago and can get some 3F products easily. In all, I was very surprised that there was little/no wheatiness about it, compared to other wheats. Then again, this is an All-American brew were talking about. Excellent hop content to make it oh so refreshing!

Much more potent than an standard wheat. You can actually see citrus particulates in the beer. Very Lemony flavor. Very clean and crisp. Head and shoulders better than Bells Oberon. I havent been disappointed with three Floyds yet. Just wish theyd get their distribution worked out so I could buy it here in Kansas City. Very solid Wheat.

Hazy yellow color and a thin bit of head.  Aroma is oh so sweat and wheatish.  The flavor feel is a bit thin, but it is more than made up for in the overall smoothness.  The flavor is delivered crisply and is a damn good standard wheat taste, with back hints of fruityness.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2005 Wow what a beer!  I had this for the first time last night.

Gumballhead has a sweet pine and citrus aroma with a hint of toasted wheat.  Not exactly sure I have had the amarillo hop before, but I can surely pick it out now - its really well done in this brew.  Its body is a nice hazy amber with very little head.  This beer has a moderately sweet and powerful but smooth floral flavor. The finish is subtly lemon with a light aftertaste of sugar and wheat.  

All and all a very good smooth beer.  Good diner beer!

Hazen pale straw yellow color, small firm white top, loose collar remains after it resides, lacings in thick strings.

Aroma has a pleasant sweet Amarillo bouquet thats just lovely, some grassyness pursues as does some floral aspects in its hop profile and the back is of dullish, lightly sugary lemon sweetness and fresh wheat.

Ooh...and ahh...a very nice taster. Sweet wheat front, dullest of dull lemon, floating grasses, great sugary return. Finishes with a slight hop drying of nonbittering pine and floral traits, left over sugars and fresh wheaty sweetness and dulled fruit drifting off. Rich, giving, smooth, and crisp, with just the right amount of everything. One well balanced and easy goin treat. I can see why gumball was intregated into the name as it has a candyish character about it.

Feel is of a perfectly drinkable medium body thats very well rounded in cabonation, smooth, lightly crisp while maintaining a certain thick and rich hold. Sweet, and a favorable fun finish of drying off dull fruity sweetness and floral hops. One hell of a tasty quencher! A sessionable ale it is true! 
Yum, yum, Ive got Gumballhead in my tum.

Great beer! Astounding Amarillo hop profile on display here.

Brewtopia 04. Between this and Southern Tier Hops Sun, two of the best wheat beers Ive had. Hops, hell yeah. Wheat, yeah some of that too. Balance? Oh yeah. Medium bodied, sweet, bitter, hoppy, delicious and did I mention hoppy? I love 3F.
On tap at Brewtopia. Clear golden in color. Crisp. Hoppy. Fresh hops.  Light flavor. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 Yum. This is officially my brew for the summer of 2004 and most likely many more to come!   Definitly not as wheat beery as i expected, like its been noted, more like a pale ale, but good none the less.   Am heading back to my local to load up a case.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2005 draught at brewtopia - I detect no characteristics of a wheat beer in this - kind of tastes like a pale ale - in fact, this tastes suspiciously like Alpha King - Im beginning to think that the common criticism that all FFF beers taste the same holds a little bit of truth - HAD AGAIN FROM A BOMBER AND WAS MUCH MORE IMPRESSED - DIDN"T TAKE ANY NOTES THIS TIME, BUT I REMEMBER IT BEING QUITE CRISP AND REFRESHING.

Poured into a tall weizen-style Oberon glass, with great anticipation.
Colors a hazy, ripe peach, head is thick, creamy cushion of meringue.
Aroma, plainly put, gorgeous! Sweet and lovely hoppiness, tingling and enticing the nose and welcoming the tongue to embrace...beautiful! I got my beak awfully wet drinking it in, and didnt want the sniffing to stop! Amarillos, they say, eh? Love my Amarillos!
Lush wheat texture greet the lips and washes over the palate, comforting and terrifically tasty. Hops continue to dance on the palate, and fruity flavors dominate. Taste gets a touch sticky and very palpable in the mouth, bringing an end to my questions about the curious appelation, sweet and gummy indeed!
(Still wonder about the crude cartoon of the smoking cat on the label, but its never normal at the House of Floyds, is it?)
Medium bodied, persistent citric finish, inestimable drinkability...hook me up to a keg and lets see, eh?
Great beer here, but then, Ive never been disappointed by the Floyds boys.
I do believe this would be my summer brew of choice, were that an option open to me...maybe it is? Who will send a case or six my way?

Tap at Brewtopia. The litttle cousin of Alpha King and Dreadnaught. Clear golden White head. Awesome fresh hop aroma. Cean crisp and light flavor, with gentle bitterness and hop flavor. Very refreshing.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: The beer relinquishes all ties with the 22 ounce brown bottle and takes up residence in my special wheat beer glass a limpid amber color, the head is modest in size, creamy in texture and a very light tan color, as it dematerializes the lace formed is a thin veil to hide the glass. Nose is spicy, citrus crisp with a nice underlying floral tone, very fresh and clean to the senses, the start is a light to the taste buds feel of the wheat and malted grain, spun sugar sweet, the top is fair to middling in its feel. Finish is ineffable in its acidity with the hops agreeable in their spicy presence, the aftertaste desert dry and long lasting, another fine beer from a fine brewery.

Why has no one thought of this before?  An easy-drinking light beer totally over-loaded with hop flavor and aroma.  I have a tough time thinking of what would make a better summer beer.  I have always liked super-charged IPA and Pils in the heat, but the bitterness dries me out too much.  This beer is just hop flavor aroma without that big drying quality (though there is plenty of bitterness).  And the malt is light , which makes it even better in hot weather.  Superb.

I had this on tap at the brewery.  Its hard to compare this to other wheats as its really in a category all its own.  The smell is dominated by grapefruit, the mouthfeel is light.  The taste again is extremely smooth with a wonderful grapefruitaftertaste.  Probably the best beer I have ever tasted.

Pours a amber gold color with a nice creamy off-white head.  Smells like a hefe plus an IPA.  Citrusy, hoppy and cloves.  Flavor is wheat, lemon, and some spice.  Finish is fast and crisp.  This is a strange beer but overall pretty good.

im pretty sure this is the first wheat beer where the hops smack you immediately. color is orange/golden, head is thin, off-white, moderately lasting. hops are the first thing i detect, come off smelling like "fresh" perspiration, then mild notes of fresh asphalt, aroma finishes with a graininess. flavor is sweaty hops (strong but not overpowering), fair amount of citrus, bitter hoppy finish...this beer is truly unique.

This beer pours a light yellow-gold with only mild cloudiness and a small lasting head.  Aroma is of wheat, hops, and a bit of lemon and sweetness.  Taste is of hops with lemon and a sweet finish.  Mouth feel is full and hearty with a dry, smooth finish.  More hops than Im used to for wheat beers, but it is excellent the way it is.  A great beer.

This is both an excellent beer and a disappointment. With a name like Gumballhead, I was looking for huge esters, but instead I found a beer that proved to me that American hops dont clash hopelessly with wheat beers after all. The color is a slightly hazy (not very cloudy at all) dark gold topped by a moderately sized white head. The aroma pits slight esters against a moderate fresh Amarillo aroma over fresh-baked bread. The flavor is a good amount of crisp wheatiness livened up with some grapefruit/juniper hops, making a very crisp, very refreshing brew. This is imminently drinkable. I could probably drink a dozen of them and fall over dead. Itd be interesting to see the same grain and hop recipe fermented on real Bavarian hefeweizen yeast instead of the yeast strain they used here.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2006 A beer I still return to occasionally. Always a pleasure. Absolutely delicious and refreshing. Has a nice small head that tops an orange and yellow body. The aroma is grass and orange peels with some pineapple. Lots of hops for a wheat beer. Gotta love the ingenuity of US brewers. This bursts on the tongue with lots of orange flavor. Tastes like biting an orange. Very light on the tongue. Similar to drinking orange flavor soda water. There is also a little tropical note of pineapple. I get a little bit of almonds. Absolutely delicious and a perfect summer beer.

poured hazy orandish color with a big off white head aroma grapefruit and lemon. flavor ruby red grapefruit with sugar on it, some sweet spices could tell what kind because of the grapefruit.this would be good for those hot days when you are just laying around doing nothing

Orange color. Has an aroma of grapefruit, and a bit of cigarette, oddly (I was drinking this at home, nowhere near cigarette smoke, by the way). A very light and refreshing beer. Very hoppy for a wheat bear, but still very enjoyable.

Pours a light clear amber with only a little head. Aroma is mild and of citrus, and a bit of fruity gum. Flavor is like a lot like alpha king with the sweet citrus hoppyness but with the addition of a bit of wheatyness and a small bit of gum in the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2004 Re-Rate  Multiple samples have increased my opinion, as the lemon tartness is very appealing.  Just that touch of spice is welcome.

 This is a wheat beer?  The hops dont add much in the aroma, but fill out the flavor.  Id consider this a mild pale ale, with some tart qualities.

Interesting brew. Pours a cloudy orangey amber with an off white head. Aroma is very hoppy and grassy. Taste is mildly sweet and spicy with a lot of hops, lemon/citrus and some wheat. Light herbal and grassy brew with good malt backing. Imagine an IPA with a slight wheat beer feel. Mouthfeel is full, round and light without being watery. Aftertaste is very mildly bitter. Good stuff.

Draft.  Light copper, slight head.  Fruity aroma of grapefruit, but faint.  Grapefruit dominates the flavor, with the body barely keeping up.  Interesting.  More of an APA than a wheat in flavor profile.  No real wheat character at all in fact.
this beer smells fruity and fun.  Mna, theres a lot of stuff going on in this beer.  I think I like this beer.  It makes me happy...and drunk!

Quite tasty for an American wheat.  I wonder if they used the same yeasts as in some of their pale ales.  Malt profile is very laid back, but the amarillo hops really have some kick.  Decent body too.  The bottom line is: like a said, quite tasty for an American wheat.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2005 Nice bright copper body with some hop flakes and a sudsy white head. Soft citrusy nose with stone fruit qualities and a hint of cheese. Flavor is wheaty with mild acidity, medium bitterness, and a citrusy finish. Hops are more prominent than in other wheat beers. Also has an almost fruit peel quality. A great refresher.

22 oz. brown bomber bottle. No freshness date anywhere on label.
Had a wimpy little pfftt when opened. Poured out a golden straw color, with a volumous white head at first that quickly slid back to a more-than-decent lacing down the sides of my wheat beer glass.
Aromas are of lemon juice, very slight and weak maltiness, yeast, and a piney, resinous hoppiness as well. The Amarillo hops make this wheat beer stand out from any other Ive had so far. Tastes are of lemon zest, slight malts, and the famous Amarillo hops. Medium mouthfeel, not too thick or too thin. Finishes crisp and hoppy. A fair to decent wheat beer, but not worth all the hype put upon it. Not by a long stretch.
I could not figure out on first tasting if this was a pale ale or an american wheat.  I definite cross collaboration of styles.  A very hoppy take on this style.

An orange amber beer, clear as a bell and with decent head and lacing. There is a strong cascade hops flavor that dominates the beverage and keeps it far from balanced. The aroma is grapefruit and orange kool-aid. It is softly sweet and certainly breaking the rules for the style. Wheres the wheat? I dont taste it. Just another hyped up Three Floyds brew.

Bottle into shaker, shared this with a friend of mine, so it was in my fridge a week.  If I buy another one, it wont last that long.  Clear, decent head, golden, citrus aftertaste.  All in all a great beer, I want this in 6 packs year long.

Clear golden body with a dense off-white head that sticks to the glass in big weeping sheets. The aroma is citurs hops,lemon. and some spiciness. No wheat detecable. The flavor is an intersting combo of citrus hops and nutty wheat malt. Very nice dry crisp finish complements the medium body. An oddball style wise but I really like it.

Clear gold-copper, slightly off whitish head leaves nice lacing.  Nose is distinctly non-wheaty, primarily quite hoppy and somewhat citric, far more like an IPA or even an IIPA than a wheat of any sort.  Flavor is also quite IPA-ish, certainly loads of hops, some toasty malts at end, sweet and sticky.  Theres a bit more of a sweetness to it in the background than most IPAs, but this, while quite good, doesnt taste anything like a wheat beer.  Can we just call it a wheat IPA and get over it?

Thanks to atpayne for this one.  Pours turbid orange/amber, with a good head and lacing.  Aroma of hops, malt, citrus, and chardonnay.  Tastes hoppy, with a nice malt backbone, and hints of citrus, yeast, peat, chardonnay, and slight honey.  Finishes hoppy, malty, slightly dry, with citrus and yeast.  Nice complexity.  A great beer.

I usually dont care for wheatbeers, but I sampled this one at the Three Floyds brewery.  The essence of wheat is very mild, which is why I was so pleasantly surprised.  It was slightly clouded in teh glass with a thin white head.  Hops were not overpowering.

This is phenomenally hopped for a wheat beer, with pungent spicy, piney hops dominating the aroma and flavor.  The wheat malt is tangy, cerealy, and a bit citrusy.  Gumballhead is hard to compare to other American wheats considering its aroma and flavor profile is quite distinct.  The body is clear straw-colored with thin off-white head (OK, so there is a similarity!).  I like this beer but its genre-splitting nature requires I compare it to other pale ales as well as wheats, and this is a "middle-of-the-pack" offering.

Pours a translucent gold with a medium white head. Aroma is hoppy and citrusy. Pleasant hop and citrus body. Very faint taste of wheat as the hops seem to overcome it. Finish is slightly bitter from the hops and the lemony notes come out. The body is fairly light and whispy which is what youd expect from a summer seasonal. Good beer!

Poured a golden color with a small white head and some lacing.  Sticky sweet hop, some lemon, and wheat aroma.  Citrus and bitter hops, balanced nicely by a sweetness and the wheat.  This is one of my favorite wheat beers!

Medium sized offwhite head, good retention and a little large bubbled lacing. Clear copper color. Nice, Big, piney nose with a hint of bubblegum. Light body, light creaminess. Fruity hops, light malts and some stone fruit flavors combine for an easy drinker. Finish is dry and fruity with a decent bite. Nice hoppy AWA.
Bottled. Golden color with a big white head. Grapefruit aroma. Flavor of wheat and citrus. Finish is slightly bitter.

Clear amber body with drippy, soap-like lacing.  Strong grapefruit aroma with green apple sweetness.  The flavor starts with the same elements as the aroma except for a dry, graininess at the finish.  I assume the husky finish is due to the wheat.  To be honest, I didnt get much out of this beer besides the hop goodness.  I think it would be best enjoyed quaffed cold on a hot day instead of served at 60F and  analyzed.

Fizzy small white head, excellent amber/gold body. There is wheat and Three Floyds Hops in the aroma, as well as in the taste. Aroma overall is a bit light. Taste is the same but I like it. There is some lemon in the taste also. Pretty good... I like the hops, but I suppose it is too much for a wheat beer.

Pours a hazy light amber with a thick white head. Hops, citrus, and fruit on the nose. Nice full mouthfeel. Light fruits, lemon and orange, hops, and light spice on the tongue. Dry bitter finish. An American wheat? Tasted like a Pale Ale. A really GOOD pale ale. Hats off to Three Floyds!!!!

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2004 Bottle pours a slightly hazy golden color, medium rocky head, pancake batter lacing, and with virtually zero carbonation.   Aroma is quite hoppy, slightly lemony, with a hint of pine needles.   WTF, This is an American Wheat?!?!   Up front I get a slightly lemony tartness, along with hops.   That is quickly followed by a slightly biscuity/malty flavor, finishing with a floral flair.   This seems more of a quasi Pale Ale/American Wheat.   Decent body and mouthfeel, just didnt know what to make of this strange concoction.   Points off for not being really true to the style.   This really needs to be classed differently.   Other than that, its still quite enjoyable.    Thanks goes out to CaptainCougar for the trade!

22oz bomberPoured a hazy straw color with a dense head that dissipates slowly. Aroma is an even blend of hops, malt and yeast with something that reminds me of crackers. Body is a bit weak and carbonation is a bit low. Flavor is of wheat malt and a slight bitterness. Yeast doesnt show up in the flavor as I would have liked and promise of lemon is faint at best. Overall a fair wheat Beer. Thanks to npdempse for the sample.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Draft - fairly standard wheat appearance.  Nice golden with a white head.  Very unique flavor.  The predominant flavor was that of LIME!  Ive seen no other rating saying so, but that is what I got.  Thirst quenching and very refreshing.  I really enjoyed this one!

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2004  AT THE BREWERY: had this from the bottle (good) and then on tap (better) and finally at the brewery (best).  Hard to believe this is a wheat.  This is awesome and is a refreshing and satisfying drink.
<be>

ON TAP:  Bought half a case and thought it was just okay.  Then I had it on tap at Crane Alley.  Much, much better.  Slightly cloudy amber with weak white head.  Wonderful bouquet of citrus hops.  Medium body.  Flavor had a pleasant citrus tang to it.  Certainly better on tap than from the bottle.
This is certainly one of the best of its style. Bright, fruity nose. Thirst quenching with great malt depth and a zesty citrus finish.
Super hop nose and palate. Unlike any other American Wheat that I have tried. This beer tastes too much like Alpha King. Alpha King JR.?

Thanks to Marinaro500 for this 3F specialty!  Pours dark golden with a fluffy white head that diminishes liesurely.  Doesnt seem particularly wheaty.  Aroma is big on the hops, slightly sweet - almost IPA-ish in character.  Flavor is good, smooth sweet start with a bold citrus hoppiness and a tangy finish.  Great summer beer!  Light to medium body and prickly carbonation.

More 3 Fs in MD...sweet!
Dark amber, lasting white head with great lace.  Aroma is all about lemony citrus hops.  Just a nice change of pace from the the "BIG" brews.  Flavor is certainly lemony, citrusy, spicy, and wheaty.  Medium bodied, smooth, velvety, quick dry finish.  A summer thirst quencher without the ABV kick.  As the weather warms, find some asap.....

Wow!!!  This is wheat beer?  Aroma is very hoppy, delightfully so, but rather different for the style.  Beer pours dark golden with a not real big off white head that is retained and has nice lacing.  There is a lot happening in the flavor department with this one.  Initial flavor is purely hoppy, but then the beer broadens and you notice the wheat flavor.  There is also a nice dry spicy finish.  Not very style specific, but excellent beer nonetheless.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2004 The nose is wonderful and freshly hopped(peachy,apricot),some malt and some more hops.Pours out a hazy deep golden w/a few yeasties,great head and lace.The taste is pretty hoppy(like a nice APA)the Amarillo hops suggest a mellow IPA.A touch of sweet and for being a wheat beer that is the last thing you taste then you burp up some bubblegum(yum)Very silky medium mouthfeel with a nice hop presence(not super hoppy)This is the ultimate wheat beer(period) for hop lovers.Surprised to find it in MD(Ronnie's should have this and Dreadnaught next week)A must try.Surprisingly complex.

Medium head, with decent lacing. Amber in color. Nose is malty with a hint of citrus friut. Slightly bitter, clean. Finishes with a slightly bitter lemony aftertaste. Not bad...Reminds me of their Alpha King....

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2005 UPDATE 2/27/05: the highlight of this brew is the aroma. there is an awesome nose that inevitably resinates the sooo deliciously sweet aroma juice, which is so inviting! carbonation seems a little bit low for my wants, though, but the overall palate makes up for it, which is primarily smooth and cremey, and a little doughy. the white head is cremey, too, as it slowly diminishes in a very frothy, soapy, and rocky manner. however, the body, although nice as gold and hazy, is too inactive for me. anyway, basically... this is refreshing, cremey, lemony, sweet like bubblegum (as the name suggests), and a tad fruity like banana. there is just about no spice, yeaup!  its a 3Floyds! So, its a badass IPA Wheat! (note: cleaned up past ratings to leave this one, which i feel most accurately represents my scoring.) ... much cheers for this great and paradoxical slow-session brew!

This is a very light, clear, clean straw color with golden hues.  The carbonation helps to maintain the head for some time.  It has a great floral hop aroma similar to other FFF beers.  There is a perfumy floral taste that pervails but doesn't dominate.  Also some citrus hops are present and a bit of sweetness.  This is a great tasting beer and tastes more like an IPA than a wheat, but I like it just the same.

Bottle pours a crystal clear amber with a nice white head and good lace.  The aroma is of hops and faint hints of banana.  The flavor is sweet, almost banana like, with the hop show to balance.  The body is nice and rich, with a good refreshing feel to it.  Overall, an interesting wheat.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2004 Bottle. Clear, golden with medium carbonation. Small quickly diminishing white head. Aroma is very hoppy, similar to other 3F products, grapefruit and piney (I love it). Wow, taste is powerfully hoppy, and lasting piney bitterness. A bit of bubblegum in the taste. A blind taste would place this as a pale ale or maybe an IPA. A couple months of mellowing might bring out some malty/wheaty characteristics. Super hoppy beer for the summer that is lower in alcohol. I'll be drinking this most of the summer.

Golden color with a cream colored voluminous head that does not go away. The first test glass, a small 3 oz vessel, still has an inch of foam at the bottom. Small cumulunimbus clouds lace. OK time to switch to the real deal wheat glass.  Seem a touch darker in the Aventinus glsss, but the head is still looming tall. Wheat field abuts a pine tree forest for this aroma. Light grapefruit and juicy fruit flavors. I like it, but more an APW (american pale wheat). Thanks slikwily ala Bunkypop.

Nice hopping, good citrus and wheat flavours, this would be a very good beer if you could remove the repulsive bubblegum taste. (I can't help the fact that the smell of bubblegum let alone the taste makes me want to vomit)

UPDATED: APR 24, 2004 Pours a hazy copper with a thin white head. Lacing is leaving thick bands on my glass.

Smell is very amarillo dominated. I thought for a second that I was sticking my face in a box of Fruity Pebbles, mmmm. 

And the taste, holy crap is that stuff good. It's hop heavy with just tons of sweet smooth amarillos, but the balance is there most definitely. Citrus flavors move in and out on the tongue at different times.

Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth and that sets it head and shoulders above all the other American wheat beers.

Drinkability is insane, one bottle was not enough, it is so good I and low abv and smoothness makes me just want to drink this all afternoon on the back porch. Summer beer of the year this year for sure!

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2004 Re-Rate 5/8/04 from bottle-Even Better from a bottle.  So aromatic-gives most IPAs a run for their money.  

Probably the best Amer. Wheat made because its actually somewhat interesting and not just a bland, low hopped ale.  I think the Floyds would do very well if they started bottling this, as its more mainstream that most of their beers.  I could drink this all summer long.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 Light orange, soft glowing color.  Very nice spiced aroma of gummibears (sugar), rum, rye, ginger, and some soapy qualities, but not very strong or pungent.  Very dry and acidic palate, soapy (oily) texture throughout the drink.  Intensely sweet.

Bottled from the growler sent to slikwily.  Pours a beautiful clear amber/orange with a thick diminishing white head.  Nice floral aroma with grapefruit and a hint of pine.  Medium palate.  Amazing flavor of grapefruit, pine, malt and wheat, although the wheat is somewhat hidden. This is an interesting american wheat to say the least.  Very tasty and very drinkable with a nice hop bite.  Big thanks to slikwily (and bunkypop) for this one.

Growler.Nice tall white head that had a decent amount of hang time.Orange in color,very hoppy,fruity aroma with shall i say an almost bubblegum like appearance in the aroma as well.Sweet and very floral with a nice showing of grapefruit.The flavor is wheaty and medium hoppy with a light grapefruit very smooth and highly drinkable,which the aroma would say other wise.the after taste is light and fruity with a nice hop tone to it.This is one hell of a brew and a wheat for that matter.Well worth getting if you can find it and this one is compliments of Bunkypop Thanks for making the trip bud.

very pale body, thin white head.  piney and resinous hop character.  pale malts, biting and spicy, piney hop character.  dry wheaty and pale.  clean and crisp.  lively palate, well hopped for a wheat.  interesting

BIG Oktoberfest:  They didn't show up until an hour in to the tasting, and still had the biggest crowd there.  I even saw one guy running to get to the line.  And now I know why.  A great brew. Reddish color with a white head.  Hoppy aroma If there was wheat in the beer, I couldn't really taste it.  I could taste the hops though.  Very tasty.
Golden brown with no head, sweet concentrated nose with a slight wheat or citrus nose. Good wheat taste and good subtle aftertaste. Overall, very good

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2004 What can we say about a wheat beer from the Floyds?  Well, it's a lot hoppier than any other wheat I've ever tried.  An absolutely great variation on the American wheat...Three Floyds does it again!

P.S. ---The draft is FAR better in my opinion than the bottle (above rated is draft).  Seek it out on tap!
Clear and pale with a head that dissipates rather quickly. The citrusy Amarillo hops are evident in both aroma and flavor, great hop flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2004 Pours a clear deep gold color, and it is topped by a tan head.  A wonderful aroma of candied fruit rises up from my glass, the aroma definitely lives up to its name.  I smell notes of apricot, lemon, and grapefruit.  The taste is light bodied, and slightly sweet, and thick with pungent hop flavors.  A clean crisp beer hides under the domination hop flavors of apricot and lemon.  this beer is not overly bitter, like perhaps the hop flavor and aroma my suggest, it has a medium level of bitterness in the finish.  I definitely know of no gumball that is quite so exquisite as this elixir.  This is a damn good Summer offering, certainly not a traditional wheat beer, but the wheat lightens this beer up and makes it a great summer refresher.  This is a straight forward, one-dimensional attack of Amarillo hops, if you like them then this is the beer for you.

Sampled at the Great Taste of the Midwest. Positioned as a hoppy wheat. I love the way these guys think. Faint hemp aroma. No head to speak of...deep gold in color. Very heavily hopped for a wheat. Very nice flavor. I could drink this as a session beer. I am becoming more and more impressed with 3 Floyds.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2003   Orange body, not as cloudy as most wheats. Aroma of strong citrus and hops. Malt flavors consists of orange, grapefruit, light notes of lemon, very little wheat. Finish is extremely hoppy for the style,  bit spicy as well. A nice innovative wheat.

Red orange color with gut foam, not obtrusive but definitely present, nice citrus blossom and honey aroma. Great balanced wheaty flavor, with that juicyness others have noted but balanced with floral hop flavor and quenching bitterness. One of the better "American wheat" style beers I've had, not bland and light like some.
Weird!  Has a fruity, (yes, a bit like Juicy Fruit) taste.  I didn't know this was a wheat when I ordered it, and wasn't sure afterwards.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2004 11-17-04  From the bottle.  Much better nose.  Still too hopped for the style, but a nice beer.  (old rating starts here-->)On tap at the brewery (and admittedly in a plastic cup).  Cloudy yellow with a bubbly head.  Crisp hop nose and lots of hop bitterness in the flavor.  Lots of grapefruit tastes.  I thought it was thin and that the flavors didnt really balance well.  Interesting take on a summer wheat beer.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2004 2004 edition, Bottled. Bought a bomber bottle at the brewery, and it must have just come off the line. It pours with a big smell of fresh, green hops that just dazzles the nose. Foamy head more pilsner than wheat style. I think the smell helped overwhelm the grapefruit taste of the amarillo hops, because I couldn't find it easily. Maybe once it's sat for awhile, it will be closer to the way it tasted last year, but man, it's still great!
On tap, at the brewery, 2003. While my experience points are still low around here, I'll stick my neck out and say this is quite unlike any other beer out there. American Wheats are a little bland, unless they've been brewed with the spicy flavor of German wheats, but the Floyds never cared for following style. This has a big zesty wheat taste that I somehow guessed was North Dakota winter wheat, and Nick said I was right, but I don't know how I knew. Like with most 3F beers, there's a big smack in the face of hops, this one is all Amarillo, giving a different more orangey taste. Pleasing orange color, too. Gotta get out and find this stuff while it's around!

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 On Tap at the brewery:  Cloudy yellow/orange color.  Big grapefruit hops aroma, thinnish mouthfeel, starts and ends bitter.  No real wheat character and basically an American IPA.
Huge apricot, passionfruit hop aroma.  Amarillo all the way.  Straightforwardish wheat beer, that shows some wheat stickiness on the tongue.  Nice summer quencher.

Tan/beige.  Moderately cloudy.  Huge citric dry-hop aroma.  Didn't peg it for Amarillo, but I've had trouble pegging that hop in the past so no big surprise.  Clean pale malt flavours, a bit of bitterness.  Wheat shows only in the finish, alongside lemon.  A different take on the style, though I didn't get the phenols promised by the name.
UPDATED: MAY 24, 2004 Yeasty, wheat aroma.  Well hopped for a amber, not less a wheat beer.  Grassy lemon flavor.  Good wheat beer.

(draft):  Medium head atop yellow-brown body.  Aroma is medium sweet, some tart, wheaty, lemon, mint herbal.  Taste is mild sweet, spicy, light mint, some fruit, finishes light grassy/herbal.  Light body and light acidity.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2007 Draft... RBSG2003... Not your fathers wheat beer. Dense as Hell!
A clear, deep yellow brew. Mid-sized, creamy white head with good lacing.
The nose is full of floral and evergreen hops. Very earthy with notes of oak and pepper.
The flavor is bold and perfectly balanced. Nicely bitter with heavy, damp straw.
Full-bodied with a syrupy/oily mouthfeel. Long, acrid, lightly bitter finish. Not my favorite style by a long shot, but a quality brew nonetheless!
Vegetable organic aroma (some carrot I found, oh yes!). Unique wheat. Very green and organic .Some spice, little malt and hops. Gets hopier with finish. Hard to rate because if its style. I liked it.
On tap-3F Brewery. Darker yellow with thin head. Has a full hop aroma and is hoppy on the tongue. No noticeable wheatiness IMHO. Finishes slightly bitter.

A super hoppy brew with light foam and a really nice, fresh (slightly cakey, sweet) aroma.  At the same time, it's tart but not bitter. The flavor is good, but seems short-lived. I'm not sure why it's called Gumballhead - must be an inside joke, since it's not at all candy.

On tap @ the brewery, RBSG2003. Fresh and hoppy and ultra crisp - slightly fruity, not sweet, not bitter, quite good. Can't get the normal American Whet components because ofthe hopping, but I still liked it!
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2004 Draft at the Brewery.  This brew pours a small head of fine to medium sized white bubbles and a weak whaet yellow body.  It had a mild malt-hop aroma.  Its flavor contained the typical 3 Floyds hop bite that is strong initailly yet softens in the finish.

Bottle:  This brew poured a small head of frothy finely sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body was a carbonated transparent orange color with a few yeast particles floating in it.  The aroma was floral and hoppy.  The mouth feel was initially tingly with a hop presence and finished with a smooth hoppy aftertaste.  The flavor contained notes of hoops malt and mild caramel.

On tap at brewery. Medium yellow with an average sized rocky head, good lacing. Light to medium-bodied. Shocking aroma, very hoppy with hints of passion fruit, mint, orange, light molasses, and dough. Fruity and tart tasting, but still clean and refreshing. Lively and dry mouthfeel. A hop lovers wheat, nice summertime brew.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2004 ReRate-22 oz bomber-pours light orange with minimal white head.  Lots of hop aroma that smells like the best homebrewed pale ale.  lots of surupy sweet amarillo hops.  This is an awesome wheat beer!  This brew has the most robust palate for a wheat beer.  4.8%?  I  think this version is a little higher.  India Wheat beer?  I think so.  This one is even hoppier than i remember last years version.  My only gripe is that its filtered.....

Hmm, this is a pretty hoppy wheat beer, probably to hoppy for most.  The aroma is full of amarillo hops.  palate is full with hints of clove and orange, somewhat like that of oberon.  There is not much malt, but since when do wheat beers have malt?

Two toned: light golden at the bottom turns a hazy golden orange/brown at the top.  A constant stream of bubbles raises from the bottom of my glass.  Large hoppy/grapefruit rind aroma - some nice sweetness as well.  Lots of orange and grapefruit flavours, very drinkable, but it is dominated by the hops. . . if you like that you'll enjoy this one.

Pours a clear golden hay color with a thin, persistent white head.  The aroma is of sweet hop juice, not too unlike AK or Dreadnaught.  The malt is incredibly subtle and light and doesn't really have much presense.  Especially considering the hops.  Don't get me wrong, I don't dislike it, but the malt doesn't move me and I don't think it's meant to.  This is an APA-lover/IPA-lover/Hophead wheat.  The hops aren't bitter, they just provide a nice flavor, which dominates the malt.  Refreshing and very drinkable.

Another great brew and we are beginning to expect nothing less.  Usual hop presence.  This beer reminds me of 1/3 Alpha King mixed with 2/3 Michelob wheat.  Very dry, refreshing and the hop is in the background.  This one is soon to be available in 22 oz bombers.
funky nose, got me excited.  spicey piney, a bit musty, really crazy.   spicey the whole way with a bit of hops.  damn good

A nice combination of an apricotty, hoppy pale and a light summer American style wheat.  Not cloudy and thick or lemony like a German wheat, but clean and refreshing nonetheless!   The signature hoppiness that I love from 3F with the slight biscuity (but not drying) touch that must be the wheat.  I can't wait until we have some hot weather here, because this will be a perfect thirst quencher.

Pours to a small, frothy head that lingers in a laced whisp.  Color is light gold, slightly murky but not too actively carbonated.  Aroma is light, hoppy and somewhat sweet, (appropriately) like a spring blossom.  Taste is lightly sweet, lightly hoppy, very pleasant and refreshing.  Dull (meaning "blunt" or "flat" but not "boring") wheat taste with a touch of malt meets the sweetness and hops with a little bit of fruit; very welcome to find moderately strong hops with almost no bitterness.  Gumball?  A little bit, and the name only adds to this beer's charm.  Almost no alcohol flavor, which is not surprising.  Finish is more complex than average, but does not hold like one would hope.  Still, that only really encourages you to take another swig of this free-flowing goodness.  If it held a little longer and/or burst a little more with its flavor, this would be a real winner.  Good stuff, as it is.

The aroma here is pure Three Floyds hopped up hop hop.  Floral, grapefruit, lemon.  The nose integrates well with the first sip and those are the major flavors that come through.  In the middle and end the wheat presents itself nicely.  An interesting take on the style.

Aroma is fruity--grapefruit and apricots. Color is quite orange, very clear. Was expecting this to be something in between SN's summer beer and Oberon--in other words drinkable but boring--but the hop kick really makes this one interesting. A somewhat musty wheat base is overlaid by a seriously bitter apricotty hop dosage. Finishes very dry, leaving you wanting more. Once again, 3F puts a unique spin on a style and pleases the palate.

On tap at FFF and Bone Dry. Golden orange color, good carbonation level, medium mouthfeel. Amarillo hop aroma hits immediately. Very citrusy first flavor, with nice sharp bite to follow. Could be hazier to indicate wheat. Wheat is subservient to the hoppiness...but what do you expect? IMO,at FFF it's this "arrogance" that keeps pushing the frontiers of flavor forward.

On tap at 3Floyds: Amber orange in color with a full short-lived eggshell head.  Big floral hoppy aroma, but what did you expect.  Smooth moderately bitter body with a dry piney finish.  Not like many American wheats I've had.  It's a decent beer, but I couldn't taste any wheat in it, and yes I'd also have to say it's over-hopped.  Reminds me too much of Alpha King.  I was hoping for a little more variety of Three Floyds brews.

On tap at brewery: I would definitely not guessed this an american wheat if Nick hadn't told me.  Amarillo hops just plain overdone and like many of their other beers, too many hops.  I found the malt in this beer being smothered by a high alpha acid hop.  A good beer, but just plain arrogance to keep hopping a style to death.

Tated at the brewery. This beer deviates from the typical 3F's MO as it is heavy in hop flavor and aroma while light in the bitterness realm.  The amarillo hops provide a very floral and lemon zesty aroma with a similar flavor profile and a subtle grassy overtone.  The beer is light golden in color and has a nice head that maintains throughout the beer.  A very drinkable offering from the Floyds!
